Through it all runs the touching story of an outsider making a new home for himself, and discovering that in the end, whatever our differences, "anyone in London can fit in."

It rightly and joyously gets to celebrate things that are rarely found in films set in modern-day Britain, such as political idealism and activism, community spirit, political bookshops, and sympathetic trade-unionists.

movie_title: Next Time I'll Aim for the Heart (La prochaine fois je viserai le coeur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While sweet and occasionally waggish, it's too predictable to transcend mindless entertainment.

There's a horror film in here somewhere, with the creepy synth score and the recurrent close-ups of twisting, blemished faces, but Silver wisely demurs: the stench of spiritual decay is disturbing enough.
Though sluggish in the middle section, the film is nonetheless effective in illustrating how a star as incendiary as Joplin could dim and ultimately die in the spotlight.

Mockingjay - Part 2 is morose, gruesome, and, at times, exhilarating. We want Katniss to win, as we always have, but it's also edifying to watch our hero learn that there are no winners in war, only losers, until someone decides that the war must end.

Suffragette falls short on inclusivity and depicting flaws within the movement, of which there were many. The women represented here are brave and often awe-inspiring, but the film could have been much braver.
Trainwreck thunders into theaters with enough hilarity and heart to make Amy Schumer, if there had been any doubt, a bonafide movie star.

Through Girlhood, Céline Sciamma captures the emotional minefield of adolescence and, more specifically, the intensity of female friendship, with a visceral blow to wherever those memories lay dormant.
In look and feel, Hector and the Search for Happiness is a cross between The Secret Life of Walter Mitty and Eat Pray Love and is only marginally better than those films.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Clipping by at a speedy 145 minutes, Gone Girl suffers only slightly from a script heavy on the exposition and leading dialogue, because, ultimately, the writing is too damn good to dislike.
The Best of Me's chemistry lives in the idea of a second chance at first love - would you take it if you could? - but not between the actors, unfortunately.
The film's scarce glimpses of humanity should add up to more, but ultimately, Listen Up Philip leaves us wondering why we bothered to care.
A shrewd little dramedy directed by a woman, written by a woman and told from a woman's perspective, which on those merits alone constitutes a rare and special film worth seeing.
Diplomacy induces pins and needles from the get-go and doesn't let up until the credits roll.
Although well-acted, cleverly executed, and spiked with a couple of series-high moments, Mockingjay, Part 1 is not nearly as exciting as the films that preceded it
Benedict Cumberbatch gives a superbly nuanced performance, imbuing Turing with just the right amount of strangeness to make him endearing but not treacly
McKay cowrote The Big Short's screenplay with Charles Randolph, and they know how to keep an audience engaged, broadcasting this knowledge often, as both parody and indictment.
This comedic caper resembles Wes Anderson's jaunty Bottle Rocket in plot, style, and a dusty-bright visual aesthetic, but it's infused with Twain's acerbic humor.
Unfortunately McCann's eerie atmospherics and masterful weaving of flashback sequences into the narrative can't save the movie from encroaching cliché.
Codirectors Timothy Kane and Annika Iltis provide helpful graphics between scenes and provide plenty of context as to why one would choose to push one's body and mind to their breaking points.
movie_title: The Barkley Marathons: The Race That Eats Its Young (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This unnecessary sequel reunites most of the cast from the 2002 indie sensation and then lazily recycles its narrative, score, themes, catchphrases, and sight gags almost beat for beat.
Writer-director Justin Lerner and cowriter Katharine O'Brien use silence as much as careful dialogue to spin a hypnotic narrative from difficult subject matter.
Cohen, brilliant in his craftier and more avant-garde shock-humor roles, is too irritating to make this character likable, much less lovable as the story demands.

As the creepy title might suggest, the movie explores the danger of detachment in modern warfare, recording the complex moral and political debate among characters charged with making life-or-death decisions.
This indie comedy could have been a brutal yet endearing midwestern cult classic a la Drop Dead Gorgeous (1999), but instead it's petty and repulsive.
This might have worked better as a more cohesive documentary.
movie_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [Butler and Eckhart's] mildly diverting performances aren't enough to dislodge the film's troubling pro-engagement message.
Dinklage is awful as the foppish villain, and aside from one uproarious, ad-libbed riff, McCarthy seems to be on autopilot.
The questions posed about journalistic ethics, personal integrity, and the problematic high of wartime reporting are all worth considering.
This inspirational heart-warmer from director Dexter Fletcher is the cinematic equivalent of a hug.
Neither the flimsy script nor Alireza Raisian's unfocused direction gives one a compelling reason to care whether any of the relationships, least of all the central one, will survive.
Greenaway gets lost in his own panache, allowing the narrative to unravel.
Fans of X-Men will gobble it up, especially lewd teenage boys; newcomers to the Marvel Universe may miss some of the best zingers.
This charming and frequently hilarious romp jumbles the stale conventions of the rom-com genre to delicious effect.
Palmer is an appealing screen presence, and Walker is passable in his crying scenes, but together they're as bland as the lines they often appear uncomfortable uttering.
Ultimately squashed by a silly and generic love triangle that makes The Hunger Games look like Casablanca.
Fuentes-León leaves many narrative loose ends, but the film's surrealism enhances its meditation on the artist's creative process.
In the style of Borat, director Jonathan Kesselman and cowriters Jobrani and Amir Ohebsion use raunchy, puerile humor to jab at American prejudices toward the Middle East.
The depths of Barr's character are left unplumbed, while other media personalities like Michael Moore and Rosie O'Donnell gush about her cultural impact.

The motif of a faceless, imaginary spaceman following the boy around is overly precious, but what does work is Tipping's focus on sensitive boys hardening in reaction to their father figures (or lack thereof).
Almost laughable in its broad, empty portrayal of sexual desire.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even through this more personal lens, Folayan and Davis take an evenhanded approach: civilians loot stores and burn police cars, whereas police officers fire tear gas and aim rifles at peacefully protesting crowds.
This striking animated adaption of a Brothers Grimm fairy tale makes a lean and dark story feel sweeping and warm.
movie_title: The Girl Without Hands (La Jeune fille sans mains) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Not wasting a minute of its two-and-a-half-hour running time, this remarkable documentary echoes O.J: Made in America by examining the Los Angeles riots.
Even as the clock ticks, the narrative drags, in large part because writer-director Desmond Faison includes several unnecessary scenes and side characters.
The climax suffers from unimpressive visual effects, but not enough to sink the measured, atmospheric buildup of the first two thirds or the exquisite performance from Geislerova.
Though flecked with dark humor, the film is a chilling reminder of what people can get away with, and what can become normal, if one consents to an oppressive system.
Jenkins tries not only to include men on Wonder Woman's side but also to make male viewers feel better about a woman saving them.
The result is a creepy experiment in nonlinear storytelling that successfully blurs reality, memory, and fantasy.
Without being overly political, Ayouch touches on the hypocrisy of gender norms in the Middle East.

Yet the clever premise fails as many of the running gags and attempts at old-fashioned slapstick fall flat. Aiming for broad comedy, Peretjatko delivers his message with a wink, though the explosive subject calls for a bang.
movie_title: La lutte pour la vie (Struggle for Life) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: They grapple with various issues connected to their race and gender, yet Hamoud keeps the tone relatively light, the women's wit and vibrancy accentuated by a brisk pace and Itay Gross's colorful cinematography.

Nodding to Spike Lee's Do the Right Thing and Kevin Smith's Clerks, this sophomore feature exemplifies the grunge and angst-ridden energy of the 90s, with a humorous streak as frank as its racially charged title.

The period setting provides some fun costumes, hairstyles, and musical cues... the humor comes mainly from the protagonist's interactions with his new friends and the endearing specificity of their situation.

The metaphor may seem obvious, but Anthony's blend of well-researched scientific and historical background with deep existential questioning recalls Werner Herzog's best work, presenting a fresh take on a centuries-old subject with poetry and urgency.

[Okwui] Okpokwasili uses song, dance, and soliloquy to explore, with a political edge, the intricacies of black girlhood, and onstage she's a magnetic force, physically commanding and emotionally raw.
[Polina] is a fine example of visual storytelling.
... this is a fun ride.
... a valuable meditation on generational differences, particularly between gay men who lived through the worst years of the AIDS crisis and those who came of age afterward.
Freed appeals to women's biological urges-to secure a protective mate, to nest, to procreate-and depends on them leaving their brains at the theater door.

Cage and Blair, both giving their best performances in years, revel in the black comedy and social satire while also giving emotional weight to the parents' resentment, toward the kids and each other.
I, Tonya seems to implicate the viewer in Harding's cultural abasement, rhetorically asking: It should've been about the skating, but you didn't really care about that, did you?
Theodore Collatos amplifies dread in interesting ways, tinting the screen red when the couple fight and inserting jerky dream sequences of a confused, bleeding hen.

What's most interesting to me about The Last Jedi is Luke's return as the mentor rather than the student, grappling with his failure in this new role, and later aspiring to be the wise and patient teacher.
[For Ahkeem] is a compelling but often frustrating documentary, a microcosm of the struggles faced by many disadvantaged young people of color today.
The second half is chilling and well directed, culminating in a high-wire act of a finale.

Ivanova is a fine actor, but her character lacks dimension; the nurse's sordid environment and the abasement she endures to the point of numbness make her feel like a personification of the country's political corruption and social unrest.

Philippe's geekiness is infectious. His passion for film shines through most when he invites some of his interviewees-like horror nerd Elijah Wood and his friends-to watch the film on camera and comment on its foreshadowing and subtle motifs.
Eschewing interviews, he, cinematographer Blaise Harrison, and editor Julie Lena craft a compelling narrative through a mosaic of scenes.
The latest provocation from Japanese director Sion Sono is an awkward theatrical cut of his nine-episode miniseries for Amazon Prime Japan
The visual style and narrative are imaginative, and there's enough social commentary to give this silly caper some weight.

Tracing every step of Lucky's protracted daily routine becomes a powerful exercise in both empathy and discomfort as he ponders the meaning of life and the inevitability of death, without the balm of spirituality.
The nonlinear, dreamlike narrative focuses on internal as much as external journeys, with strangers connecting across racial, cultural, and generational divides to express wisdom or compassion.
Frothy but entertaining.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: David Oyelowo and Lupita Nyong'o are reliably superb in the critical supporting roles of Mutesi's chess coach and young mother, respectively.
Despite some awkward attempts at broad comedy, the film works as an uncomplicated reminder of what can happen when disenfranchised women speak up.
The film has a clever premise that probably would have worked as a half-hour TV episode but fails to sustain a feature-length comedy.
Though simple and straightforward, the film is a potent argument for justice, even-and especially when-the fight is ongoing.

The main characters are high school bullies, but director Ry-Russo Young refuses to stereotype them; they can be sweet and endearing one moment, petty and cruel the next, but their motivation is always clear.

Despite the touchy subject matter, Syeed avoids preaching and instead focuses on the protagonist's day-to-day struggle; the understated drama benefits also from Yoni Brook's crisp cinematography and Abdirahman's multifaceted performance.

Except for a few jocose, fan-serving moments, the movie is a dour affair, lacking the charm and chills of J.J. Abrams's spirited Star Wars: The Force Awakens, not to mention George Lucas's founding trilogy.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The narrative is a fairly predictable hero's journey -- Maui even calls her "The Chosen One" -- but the movie is refreshing for its lack of a love interest; instead Moana learns how to chart her own course.

The film benefits from Zach Kuperstein's moody black-and-white cinematography and the stark compositions, but the unrelenting ugliness and senselessness of the piece negate its occasional touches of minimalist beauty.
Ultimately the drama, adapted from a 1993 book by Austin Wright, constitutes a loose assemblage of ideas about romantic betrayal, selfishness, and regret.

Factor in the feel-good story, Bell's bracing cinematography, and his meticulous observance of the villagers' customs and environments, and the film becomes a multilayered exploration of dignity, perseverance, and progress.
This is the first feature by writer-director Kelly Fremon Craig, and despite the conventional teenpic narrative, her protagonist is richly conceived.

Ostensibly we're supposed to like Pratt and Lawrence together, yet Pratt's character does something so unforgivable to Lawrence's at the outset that their ensuing interactions simmer with a mix of horror and disbelief.
This feature-length animation by Hungarian painter and filmmaker György Kovásznai reveals a gift for jazzy, kaleidoscopic storytelling.

This 2014 adaptation of the French fairy tale looks spectacular, with vibrant landscapes and lavish 18th-century costumes, but... [Léa Seydoux, as the fair maiden, and Vincent Cassell] are stiff and perfunctory.
movie_title: Beauty And The Beast (La belle et la bête) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A haunting piece of high art.
Verhoeven masterfully stretches the suspense, and his gallows humor lands most of the time. His attempts at edginess slide into exploitation, though.
Kore-ada has explored the father-son dynamic in his previous work, most notably Still Walking (2008) and Like Father, Like Son (2013), and brings a gentle, humanist approach to the material.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Lane, whom Arnold discovered lounging on a Miami beach, recalls Jennifer Lawrence in Winter's Bone, balancing an inherent toughness with the fragility of girlhood.
Burton has covered similar ground already, but fans will relish this spooky return to form.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director James Mangold, returning after the second installment, The Wolverine, orchestrates several jaw-dropping action sequences, heightened by Jackman's and Keen's intense performances and by Marco Beltrami's taut and plunky score.
Reveals a humanist core beneath layers of dry irony and cynicism.
For this puerile farce, director John Hamburg recycles a tired premise -- a straitlaced father disapproves of his daughter's freewheeling boyfriend -- and then drowns it in moose urine (really).
What begins as a gritty, documentary-style dive into the young women's world -- they're introduced as looters during the 2011 Tottenham riots -- quickly devolves into a Lifetime movie.

English writer and theologian John Hull, who went blind in the early 1980s and kept an audio diary of his experience, is the subject of this thought-provoking film, which takes an unusual if not always successful approach to the documentary form.
[An] engaging film, exploring the link between honesty and intimacy.
movie_title: You're Killing Me Susana (Me estás matando Susana) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film benefits from Auteuil's moving lead performance, though the narrative is less exciting than it is resolute.
movie_title: In Her Name (Au nom de ma fille) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A study of grief, forgiveness, and how family history can provide a greater understanding of oneself.
Seems to last forever and, when it finally ends, leaves a sour aftertaste of overproduced, overblown schlock.
Of the five live-action shorts nominated this year, three focus on personal fulfillment... The other two shorts are overtly political, and they throb with an urgency the others lack.
This romantic fantasy works on a conceptual level, but not in execution.
Even more entertaining the second time around.
Why these two women are attracted to each other beyond looks is a mystery; eventually they swap backstories, but neither is compelling enough for one to invest in the character.
The premise... demands more heat and complexity than this hokey 2016 drama provides.
Director Luc Jacquet struggles to dredge up the sort of emotion he delivered so easily in his Oscar-winning March of the Penguins (2005).
movie_title: Antarctica: Ice & Sky (La glace et le ciel) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is only slightly less dumb and nonsensical than the previous films, but it teems with thrilling action sequences and rollicking stunt work from the middle-aged Diesel and martial artist Donnie Yen.
Filmmaker Lloyd Kramer (Liz & Dick) delivers powerful vignettes involving three families... but shies away from such issues as the plague of gun violence and the rise of angry young men in America.
Gad's voice-over often seems incongruous with the dogs' onscreen behavior, and he's rarely as funny or touching as he tries to be.
The plot may be predictable, but the leads have nice chemistry and writer-director Gustavo Ron sprinkles in some funny and touching family moments.
movie_title: Bakery in Brooklyn (My Bakery in Brooklyn) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The script teems with horror clichés (scribbled drawings, a creepy kid, the skeptical protagonist looking up the demon's origins on a library computer), and everything from the acting to the makeup to the special effects is atrocious.

This corny sci-fi drama abounds with annoying plot holes and product placements, and the 2017 teenspeak ("You ghosted me!") will probably sound dated to anyone watching the movie even a few years from now.
Pleasant is the perfect word with which to describe The English Teacher, an ingratiating little comedy that aims to please and succeeds at its modest goal.
The movie, thank goodness, is better than the book. What's more surprising is that The Bridges of Madison County is an accomplished piece of moviemaking.
The Hand that Rocks the Cradle, though it positions itself as chilling suspense, is not even mildly scary; it's just offensive.
movie_title: The Hand that Rocks the Cradle (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Part of what makes Way, Way Back so engaging are the terrific performances.
All this doped-up ennui eventually proves wearing. Junkies, given to nodding out and living in squalor, don't make good company for too long.
The plot, trifling as it is, doesn't much matter. What makes the movie such a hoot are the clever gags, imaginative special effects, and the snappy byplay between the well-matched Jones and Smith.
Like festive icing on a plain vanilla cake, a fun cast and offbeat humor hugely increase the palatability of Post Grad.
A cloying romantic comedy.
It's all very disappointing.
Had Billion Dollar Movie been just eight minutes on the Funny or Die website, where Heidecker and Wareheim have often appeared, it might have worked.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The fact that Guillermo del Toro is an executive producer of Mama is a tip-off that this won't be just another horror film with misbehaving and soon-to-be-dismembered teenagers or a drooling, slime-soaked monster.
When it comes to mining a medical malady for laughs across multiple platforms, standup comic Mike Birbiglia is a master.
The performances, especially by Zissis and Lafleur, are effectively low-key, making their characters' occasional emotional outburst all the more compelling.
Hysteria is a fun fling of a movie about medical science at its shakiest. Literally.
Part of Mirror's problem is that the screenplay, credited to two writers and with a third getting a story credit, is all over the place.
What gives this latest Disney cartoon a real excitement is its story, a swift, sometimes brutal tale of dynastic trouble in the animal kingdom.

Overall, Jolie has nothing to be embarrassed about and much of which to be proud with this movie. Even in moments where the film doesn't quite work, she shows ample evidence of ambition and a discerning director's eye.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, the movie is about healing and coming to understand that some things can't be explained.
Sadly, Red Tails tells its inspiring story in the most old-fashioned, Saturday-afternoon-at-the-movies kind of way. The movie occasionally flies but it never soars.
For action fans, the film delivers action. Beyond that, not so much.
In the end, a viewer can do little more than appreciate Dead Man's shimmering look and wish all involved better luck in their next endeavor.
Cage is good, Travolta is better. There is a glee to his performance, a sheer joy at playing two roles in one. He's having a rip-roaringly good time, and so are we.
E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial still evokes laughter, tears and that heart-lifting surge of joy only a great movie can bring.
After seeing Ryan, many of us will look at our aging fathers or grandfathers with a newfound respect.
The story grows more complicated (sometimes too much so) but the heart, humor and luscious, mostly hand-drawn animation remain constant.

In the dictionary, "frothy" is defined as being "light and entertaining but of little substance." This Means War is a totally frothy film. And that's a good thing, at least here. (Sometimes substance is overrated.)

I'm still not as blissed out by this trilogy as are hardcore fans of the J.R.R. Tolkien novels or filmgoers who revel in endless battle scenes. Still, this end chapter is as visually spectacular -- with its mythological creatures -- as movies get.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: All this plays like a giant game of Myst, with Ring's mythical characters never making the leap from virtual reality to real.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The film doesn't make a strong case for Judge to move beyond cartoons to live actors.
Over time, the rhythms of small-town life and the eccentricities of its residents can grow on you. That's exactly what happens as you watch this sharply observant movie.
28 Days Later is a mind-bending look at a future one hopes never happens.
Pegg, who cowrote Shaun with director Edgar Wright, shows off expert timing, whacking punchlines and zombies with equal panache.
Don't go see The Blair Witch Project alone; it's too scary to sit through without company. Thrillingly, nauseatingly so.
As Kline begins to take his presidential duties seriously, the comedy seeps out, a listless civic-mindedness drifts in like fog off the Potomac.
If ultimately there is less to Sense than meets the eye, director-writer M. Night Shyamalan (Wide Awake) at least avoids gory cheap thrills in favor of muted chills. He bears watching.
For summer popcorn fun, this movie has it all: special effects, romance, action and humor.
A smart, intricately constructed thriller, the film has far more on its mind than just who done it.
Pixar's fourth feature for Disney is yet another miracle of computer animation, an instant classic, but with less of the surface brightness of Toy Story or Monsters, Inc.
A well-told and beautifully drawn tale of friendship and fortitude.
With its winking homages to films like Stalag 17 and The Great Escape, Run is visually inventive, its characters plump with personality and, for a bunch of chickens, ever so brave.
In playing a career criminal who can't get a break, Clooney has finally found a movie role that adroitly showcases his smoldering good looks and smart-aleck demeanor.
This is easily the best Harry Potter film yet, though a few qualifiers need to be added to that endorsement.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Not since 1978's Superman has there been a live-action, comic book-based film so savvy at mixing self-aware camp with sincere emotion, and so successful at establishing the normal guy life of its spandexed protagonist.

Nothing in Cliffhanger could possibly surpass that terrific opening jolt, but it's a smart, enjoyable summer action thriller nonetheless, directed by Renny Harlin with the focused energy of a Boy Scout earning badges.

What makes Hero special is that it has so much more going for it than just the superb fight sequences. There are a satisfyingly complex plot, passionate romance, cool special effects and strong performances.
The Matrix is tough to explain, but then how much explaining does an amusement park ride require?
Despite the energetic efforts of Smith and Lawrence, Boys is yet another hyperventilating sequel with an inflated plot and running time.
If you're looking for a passable film to take the kids to this weekend, Miracle offers a smart enough take on its feel-good plot to keep adult viewers tuned in.
Project Nim nimbly serves up a profoundly sad tale that raises as many thought-provoking questions as it answers.
Vera Farmiga makes a heavenly debut as a director with Higher Ground, a compelling drama about a woman's spiritual journey.
[It] clocks in at a bloated 118 minutes. There is not, I promise you, 118 minutes worth of vital plot, special effects or comic business in this movie.
It's still more inventive, clever and laugh-out-loud funny than any other movie out there now.
Supporting characters are too hastily sketched in, serving only to further the unsmooth course of true love.
The movie won't change your life or grab a fistful of Oscar nominations come next winter. But it will make you laugh, hard and often, and it proves that sometimes girls just want to have fun.
Oh, look, it's rich people in beautifully appointed houses and they're worried that the nanny might not arrive on time for them to make important morning meetings at work. Boo-hoo.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [An] intellectually stimulating new drama about the terrifyingly rapid spread of a lethal virus.
Worthington shows a greater range and vulnerability here than he did in either Avatar or Clash of the Titans, where he mostly just flexed his pecs. He may be a genuine movie star yet.
Super 8 is accomplished commercial filmmaking.
A mighty thin and derivative slice of moviemaking.
Characters are so sketchily drawn that little is really at stake here.
One doesn't have to be familiar with Deneuve's body of work to enjoy Potiche, but it sure adds to the experience if you are.
The magic is still there, only you have to work a little harder to make yourself believe this time.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: About Schmidt is about perfect. It has heart, humor and a healthy appreciation for the frailties of human nature.
Sean Connery will always own the role, but in Die, a thoroughly comfortable Brosnan achieves optimum balance between taking this nonsense seriously and playing it with a wink.
The very fact that much of the story unfolds on a speeding bus and later on a speeding subway provides an intrinsic, inexorable sense of momentum. Speed is worth the ride.
Minority Report makes The Matrix look tame. This is big studio, commercial filmmaking at its best.
Brosnan's Bond is all lightweight bonhomie, but he is positively Oscar-worthy compared to Richards.
Any sort of compelling story gets lost amidst all the spectacle.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: This spunky, low-budget British action-comedy proves once again that a smart script can breath new life into even the most tired of subjects.
The strong stench from The Vow is likely to overwhelm the smell of popcorn in movie theaters this weekend.
There's nothing real about Real Steel except its shameless desire to please by going where better and more successful movies have gone before.
Another forgettable trifle from Cage.
Heigl, sporting tousled brunette locks, gives a busy, unconvincing performance.
No matter your politics, [Streep] makes you see Thatcher as a real person rather than a caricature.
No matter her audacity, the Material Girl is only as good as her material, and Madonna has only half a movie here.
This is an undernourished drama likely to leave most viewers muttering a puzzled "huh?" as they exit the theater.
Altmanesque in its sprawl and sympathetic attitude toward even its most flawed characters, Happy Day marks a mostly promising debut for director-writer Sam Levinson.
Depp, while always fun to watch, phoned this one in.
There are a lot of sharp performances here, a chief pleasure of the film.
[A] putrefying piece of genre junk.
Statham, he of the chiseled physique and sexily receding hairline, holds his own here, doing what he has to in scenes and no more -- which is perfect for a movie like this.
An exceedingly minor entry on already impressive resumés.
An ever-so-tasteful, watered-down and unnecessarily-improved-upon adaptation of Lisa See's bestselling 2005 novel of the same name.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a bummer of a movie -- dark and at cross-purposes with both itself and any image do-over [Gibson] might be seeking.
Anyone who has ever seen a romantic comedy before knows where this one is going.
How many more of these superheroes can we take?
Fast Five is grindingly mechanical -- and not just because of all the emphasis on car repairs and retooling.
As X-Men films go, this one gets the job done and is certainly better than Last Stand or Wolverine. But there are still just too darn many X-Men.

Accomplished filmmaking that features two highly attractive, talented leads, a healthy dose of sentiment, an intelligent script, and which takes you away for two hours from the quotidian worries and banalities of your regular life.
Its downfall is its cliché-riddled and fusty script.
Add 50/50 to your want to see list. And then make an appointment for your annual physical with your doctor.
Don't tell the kids, but Santa Claus isn't real and Pixar is fallible.
At last, a movie you can actually discuss afterward. And not just on Facebook or Twitter. No, you'll want to chew it over in person, with friends, for hours.

Supporting characters (including Jolie, who is wasted as a tiger) are pallid, and the fight scenes disproportionately long, as if the filmmakers figure the young boys most likely to see Panda are just as action-happy as their dads.
This misguided romantic comedy goes wrong so often and in such profoundly lunkheaded ways that to say it stinks would be bordering on polite understatement.

Goblet again serves up a delicious who's who of British acting, with hilarious contributions from newcomers Brendan Gleeson as instructor Alastor "Mad-Eye" Moody and Miranda Richardson as nosy reporter Rita Skeeter.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Frost/Nixon crackles with excitement, humor and the thrill of the hunt -- and Langella and Sheen couldn't be better.
A smart, snarky take on battling the undead, this comic horror-thriller pokes fun at pop culture and piles on the gore.
These Robinsons should have gone into therapy, not space.
It's like watching a movie version of Mad magazine's Spy vs. Spy, but minus the humor.
Ratatouille is a delicious delight, brimming with colorful characters, lush animation and, as Remy rises at a chic Parisian restaurant, useful culinary advice.
I challenge you not to tear up.
This is the WB version of a baseball movie. Everyone is young, toned, sexually active and agonizes over their future.
This is a messy disaster at which you can only scratch your head and mutter, "What were they thinking?"
A romantic comedy, it's such a sloppy mess that polishing it with all the Pledge in the world couldn't help brighten it up.
Perry smirks and mugs throughout while Hurley just seems massively bored, practically yawning even while hoisting her shirt for the hotel clerk.
This clichéd tale of combative Brooklyn street gangs in the late 1950s gets it so wrong in so many ways, it's almost cruel to count them.
The brief Lucy scene was funnier than anything else in the movie. If only the clip had lasted longer.
This is one of those what-could-they-have-been-thinking movies.
As premises go, this one is unusually thin, boorish and insensitive. No amount of reworking with a No. 2 pencil will do any good.
Fathers' Day scoots along pleasantly but never rises above its My Two Dads sitcom premise.
The only thing this Avengers shares with its swinging, earlier incarnation is a London setting.
Thurman aside, B&R is about what you've come to expect: loud, frenzied, brawling and fixated on sleek, shiny, high-tech vehicles and gadgetry.
Striptease is an amiable comedy with ambitions to be a satire, but its thriller plot keeps getting in the way of the yucks.
Straight out of the His Girl Friday school of newspaper romances, Trouble is anemically formulaic and completely uninspired.
Here's a splendid cautionary tale for any child who has ever, mid-tantrum, wailed, "I'll just go find my real parents!"

It's a movie you should see a second time to appreciate fully its themes of love and lust and trust and truth, but the idea of sitting through it again anytime soon may be about as alluring as eating a hairball.
Gleeson reminds us that the best acting always looks like no acting at all.
Let's just say that the movie's final section is so nail-bitingly tense, thanks to a skillful combination of acting, writing and crosscutting, that it puts Affleck in the big leagues as a director.
Bad trip. Bites. Whack. Whatever your era and whatever your slang, this new movie version of TV's The Mod Squad stinks.
Greenaway provides a visual feast, then he kills your appetite.
None of the human actors here make much of an impression.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: While Craig owns the movie, he gets much capable support. Green's Bond babe believably has more on the ball than many of her predecessors, while Dench, returning as M, Bond's boss, has perfected her sighs of exasperation.

Director Marc Forster gets the action scenes right but never shapes the film as a whole. And if Craig, a talented actor, wants to be a Bond for the ages, he needs to lighten up. James Bond shouldn't be all work and no play.
Its story [is] an unwieldy patchwork even by this series' standards.
Young fans will be amused by the duo's dopey antics, but most adults will simply be perplexed.
X2's excessively complicated and character-crammed plot, which only a teen boy could care about enough to follow closely, has a nasty human bigwig (Brian Cox) fomenting a war against the mutants.

In the inventive fight scenes, [Blade's] sword clangs, and there are sluicing sounds when it finds its target, all in keeping with the unapologetic bang! blam! pop! comic-book spin director Guillermo Del Toro brings to the film.
The Curse of the Recycled TV Series strikes again as director Barry Sonnenfeld manages to transform a mildly amusing mid-'60s TV show into a bloated big-screen bore.
Garner, who showed a promising comic touch last year in 13 Going On 30, does her movie career no favors here.
Hell is scary, but also wonderfully wacky.
Inchon is vapid and disjointed.
An admiring and amusing documentary.
A gripping story of survival on the streets and survival of the soul.
Children of Men presents a chillingly believable version of the future. It will stay with you long after the end credits fade.
There's much wit here, bang-up action scenes and a twisting plot that will make sense to those who truly care to follow it. May this latest incarnation of the series live long and prosper.
It's hard to imagine any viewer leaving this extravagantly demented, 2 1/2 hour low-life lalapalooza without carrying away at least a few indelible moments.

While neither Zellweger nor Gere have superior singing voices or terpsichorean skills, they try their best and give likable, effective performances. As for the slinky Zeta-Jones, who can sing and dance, she's pure hubba-hubba.

Movies don't come better acted, as lucidly written or, most importantly, more capable of grabbing a viewer emotionally and intellectually than this exceptional ensemble drama about racial and ethnic relations in urban America today.
Basterds has multiple plot strands that eventually converge in a spectacular finale, which takes place, fittingly, in a movie theater in Paris.

Producer Jerry Bruckheimer and director Michael Bay are slick Hollywood operators who know exactly what they're doing: Armageddon's heart beats strongly, but it's pumping adrenaline rather than blood.
Half-Blood is a sustaining visit with beloved old (if not in age) friends.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Neither of the movie's two stories makes complete sense, but that hardly matters. This is like being inside a pinball machine with a toddler at the controls.
Kudos to Crowe, who can go over the edge without going over the top.
Beauty is never less than fascinating and always visually stunning.
This sensational, gripping film is what I call an efficient epic.
Hallelujah! Men is so good it takes your breath away, even when you're not holding it during the scary parts.
A slick, slam-bang thriller about a business tycoon's frenzied efforts to get back his kidnapped son, Ransom is meant to divert and entertain. It does.

Onscreen, Eastwood is solid as granite, getting maximum effect by doing the minimum required in a scene but doing it with precisely the right inflection or look. Swank is sensational, proving her breakout turn in Boys Don't Cry was no fluke.

Moviegoers may not have been pining for such spectacles since speeding chariots last rumbled through theaters in 1959's Ben-Hur and 1960's Spartacus, but the juiced-up Gladiator proves there's still plenty of grappa left in the genre.
Though heartfelt, the film tries too hard to dazzle and thrill rather than echo its own message: just believe.
Pure joy. That's what you will feel as you float out of the theater after seeing this wacky musical whodunit starring several of France's most accomplished and best known actresses.
A hip, knowing look at how certain young men put off growing up until they are finally too miserable to postpone it any longer.
This amusingly venal, possibly shocking tale is just what Scrooge ordered.
What the movie does offer is a delectable performance by Bullock, who is funny and vulnerable and almost makes you buy her character's diving into this charade.
The animation -- from elaborate (the supernatural creatures) to simple (a rain shower) -- is superb.
The older these kids get, the darker and more engrossing the Harry Potter movies become.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Enchanted is, in a word, enchanting. It's a clever, high-spirited romp spoofing fairy tales and the animated, musical versions of them that have been around since 1937's Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.
Pan is clearly not for kids. But it is an eye-popping political fable filled with magic realism -- and real magic.

[Chamber of Secrets] is more tightly plotted than the original film and boasts a welcome, lighter touch in its early scenes. But it devolves, during its wearying 161-min. running time, into a been-there-fought-that action hero yarn.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: If fall movies were this consistently clever, there would never be reason to hesitate before plunking down hard-earned bucks at the multiplex.
No matter which level of the movie a viewer responds to, anyone past the age of 5 who doesn't laugh repeatedly while seeing Shrek needs to have his funny bone examined.
Like Chinatown before it, this twisted and twisting tale of cops, crime, corruption and hangers-on in 1950s Los Angeles artfully evokes the flip side of the City of Dreams.
It would be Scrooge-like to say mean things about the innocuous Elf, so I'll just point out that director Jon Favreau's film rarely reaches its full comic potential.
The Departed is not for the faint of heart. But scaredy-cats are going to miss a tremendously satisfying film, one that will have you leaving the theater saying, "Now, that was a movie."
At times it's even vaguely reminiscent of The Wizard of Oz, only as if illustrated by Hieronymus Bosch. It's wonderful.
Nothing here is sufficiently wild.
Get thee to the nearest movie theater showing Shakespeare in Love, a delightful comedy that sparkles with wit, literary smarts, passionate romance and expert acting by a glossy, enthusiastic cast.
Bloated and boring, Pearl Harbor is a collection of war-movie clichés.
As Morris, the reliable Quaid throws heat, delivering smoothly in dramatic scenes and convincingly from the mound.
Costner is charming as an aging catcher who decides it's time to hang up his mitt at Sarandon's place.
Its stars, young, sexy performers all, deserve a better vehicle.
The end result is a science-fiction saga so incoherent, so ugly and so pointless that you have to wonder why Warner Bros, is even bothering to distribute this embarrassment.

This is one of those big, sleek soulless movies that hums along, impressed with itself and the Big Issue it allegedly tackles... [but] what Disclosure really does best is appeal to your most prurient instincts.
The tension between romantic attraction and sexual fulfillment builds to an almost unbearable intensity.
The movie isn't so much about Kurt or Courtney as it is about shabby lives in the shadow of fame.

If cats, those snootiest of creatures, went to the movies, they would be appalled and mortified. What did they ever do to deserve having their good name and mannerisms dragged through such dingbat fluff as this?
This terrific movie, about one man's quest for vengeance, does everything a thriller is supposed to do: intrigue, involve and keep you guessing.
Once the movie decides the air is clear and Fraser begins walking the earth, Blast becomes much spottier at hitting its comic targets and suffers from a bad case of the cutes.
What's best about Wait are the bright turns by its young cast.
A gloriously inventive little comedy about the scholastic and romantic woes of a 15-year-old student at a private academy.
Aquatic seems willfully eccentric without ever letting the rest of us in on the joke.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Wilson, Brody and Schwartzman are each fine, but if you found yourself stuck in a train compartment with their characters, you'd vamoose.
This slender story is told with droll wit, clever staging and doll house charm thanks to Fox's use of old-fashioned, stop-motion animation.

It either sweeps you up in its rapturous emotional wake or -- and it's a big or -- you just sit there and snicker. I found myself alternately doing both, though fortunately more of the former than the latter.
An appealingly quirky comedy about an unhappy clan of eccentric geniuses.
DiCaprio and Winslet both deliver star-making performances.
What we are left with is perhaps one of the most disturbing 60 minutes of raw footage ever put together.
"Phil Ochs" not only is a good look at a man who carved a small but important niche into the folk world but a good record of the turbulent 1960s and what motivated its protesters.
movie_title: Phil Ochs: There But For Fortune (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Koolhoven is able to strip away both visually and mentally our idealized cinematic notions of how the resistance fighters lived. It's a lonely existence. It's stark and it's scary. And it makes for a compelling movie.
A charming little French animation (not suitable for very young children,) directed by Alain Gagnol and Jean-Loup Felicioli...
Quote not available.
Despite its fascinating and humorous moments, one can't help but be frustrated when at times it switches away to spiritual pretentiousness.
Takes on too many worlds and too much politics in what could have been a gripping, straight-up documentary about a crisis in Judaism in the United States.
Probably the scariest movie you will see all year.
Despite a too slow pace for my own tastes, Hauer helps move the film along by being captivating even in just a few scenes.
This is a fact-based story of the French resistance who had to fight not only the Germans but their own people.

Emily Watson, who always brings a special grace to the screen, gives a multilayered performance to the role of Margaret Humphreys, who not only puts her own family dynamic at risk but finds herself physically threatened.
Although we never really learn much about his life outside the movies, by the end of the film we are in awe of his work accomplishments.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Director Beth Toni Kruvant hits incredible highs and a shocking low as she explores the cultures of past and present student bodies that come together in a common cause.

This is a good refresher course for those who aren't familiar with the JFK assassination. But despite the film's attempts to close the case, there will always be questions about what happened on that November day in Dallas.
The movie is an admirable look into the venerable St. Petersburg company and how dancers thrive or just survive in the physically challenging world of dance.

What makes the movie so effective is that Rafferty uses game footage instead of interspersing the movie with cliched scenes of Vietnam protests, campus mayhem, etc. The effective use of this footage builds suspense, even though we know the result.
In the documentary America the Beautiful, Roberts explores the cult of beauty in the United States and mostly succeeds in unmasking the flaws of fetishizing skin-deep beauty.
The movie might have worked better had it stayed with the search longer and played up the plot point of the collision between the two black cultural worlds.
movie_title: I'm Through with White Girls (The Inevitable Undoing of Jay Brooks) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Director Gil Kofman's attempt is noble in trying to show this descent into madness, but something rings false.
The story isn't just about the result, but rather a look at lives and hopes that are part of our American culture.
A fascinating look into student life of the past and present.
I still loved every minute of it.
So many documentaries about the Holocaust have been shown before. One would think we've seen enough. Steal a Pencil for Me proves we can never learn too much.

For those of us old enough, it is another magical reminder of how these missions gave us some hope in very challenging times. For those of us too young, this will give you an idea of what it meant to watch those baby steps that led to one giant leap.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A good bio of any historical character has to have a compelling story, whether evil or good. Klimt appears to have had that story. I sure would have liked to know what it was.

12:08 East of Bucharest cleverly takes on the aftermath of the December 1989 revolution in Romania that resulted in the overthrow of Nicolae Ceaucescu. It's a movie that seems simple, yet its subtle and brilliant complexity is not to be denied.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: ... a quirky little comedy ...
[Captures] the essence of Carol as one of those creatures of the theater that when you see her onstage, you know you've seen something special.
In her latest film, Yoo-Hoo, Mrs. Goldberg, [director Aviva] Kempner once again educates and entertains with unexpected tidbits and just plain good old-fashioned filmmaking.
A charming and entertaining movie that instills a little fantasy into the mix.
There's much more to Aleichem the man and the writer than just the musings of a milkman.
movie_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Full of surprises, the movie draws a thin line between pity and revulsion - how would you feel if you had discovered your whole life had been based on lies?
The movie feels more like a thriller and a mystery than a documentary. Perhaps someday, someone will be inspired to dramatize this astonishing story.
The man now known as the Jon Stewart of Egypt has graced us with satirical humor that sends a loud and clear message against repression.
Entertaining fluff more suitable for the Lifetime or Hallmark channels than theaters.
movie_title: Bakery in Brooklyn (My Bakery in Brooklyn) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fields tells most of his recollections in a dry and wry way with indignation, irreverance, cynicism and bemusement.
Although we know the outcome, "Silicon Cowboys" feels like a suspense thriller.
The movie is entertaining, although true Trekkies will probably find out nothing new about the man with the pointed ears.
Klaussner's fine performance keeps us on edge through most of the film, even though we know the result.
movie_title: The People vs. Fritz Bauer (Der Staat Gegen Fritz Bauer) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What starts out as a genial documentary about two sons of high officials of the Nazi Party soon turns chilling in the gripping and compelling "What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy."
movie_title: What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A little gem.

"Félix and Meira" appears to be a simple movie about fitting in, acceptance and sacrifice. Yet it's so elegant and poses many different sides that it's actually a very complex film with very complex characters.
Bernstein in action is a study of what a teacher should be: kind but with a steely resolve. He analyzes the music and figures how to overcome its obstacles.
Although we know what happens, Diplomacy keeps up the suspense and pulls off surprises as Choltitz's decision reaches its inevitable ending.

It's not easy making an uplifting film about the aftermath of the death of a son. But director and co-writer William H. Macy and actor Billy Crudup as the bereaved father pull it off in "Rudderless," a movie more about redemption than the causes of evil.
It's definitely not love at first sight for this odd couple, which makes for good laughs, but their love of food and life enables them to find the right mix of ingredients for a very funny movie.
The documentary does a good job on his career and life, using interviews with Ellis, former teammates, family members, friends and former wives.

Imagine a blissful life taken away: Story of an Arab man who's assimilated into Israeli society but finds out that his wife was a suicide bomber. Nothing new here about the conflict, fair portrayal of the sides, thought provoking without solutions.

"The Secret Disco Revolution," claims that the steady "four on the floor" beat was the reason for the liberation of gays, African Americans and women. And oddly, in a blend of humorous and dead serious storytelling, director James Kastner makes his case.
"Still Mine" is uplifting and heartbreaking, a contradiction that results in the viewer exalting and being let down at the same time.
It's refreshing to hear dialogue that's natural and modern and doesn't try to pontificate. And the rewards are many.
"I Give It a Year" is a smart farce that would make Hugh Grant and his fans proud.
We love her, yeah, yeah, yeah.
It has its tedium, but it's not bad. At times, it's actually quite good.
Though the filmmakers take on too much in 90 minutes, they pass the test by convincing us that something needs to be done to end this financial nightmare, which can cost $60,000 per year per student.
An illuminating documentary about how Jews were front and center in building the city, both intellectually and physically.
movie_title: American Jerusalem: Jews and the Making of San Francisco (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Filmmakers Benny and Josh Safdie use real-time footage to follow this hopeful, affable young man as he becomes a bitter has-been over the course of a decade.
Director Nancy Buirski not only is able to give rare insights into the dance world but a compelling tale of love, friendship and perseverance.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Although Jones and Pearce are interesting when onscreen alone, their chemistry is slightly off.
There's nothing groundbreaking in "Cuban Fury," but it's a pleasant diversion starring the always amiable Nick Frost, with Chris O'Dowd relishing his role as a slimeball.

There are just so many ways Carine Roitfeld can say she loves fashion in "Mademoiselle C," a somewhat interesting documentary that brings us into the inner workings of a magazine, but harps a bit too much on her ideas of fashion and style.
By The Time It Gets Dark is a cinematic classic that will beg to be watched, decided and marvelled at, time and time again.
movie_title: By the Time It Gets Dark (Dao khanong) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film succeeds in portraying a faithful representation, interior and exterior, of working class life in '80s Manchester.
Bokeh's depth of field itself is ultimately too shallow, the focus not quite tight enough.
A stark portrait of sexually motivated violence, Jorge Riquelme Serrano's recent film, Chameleon, raises uncomfortable questions about responsibility and the entertainment industry.

Filmmakers Chris Metzler and Jeff Springer plunged into their subject for this documentary, detailing with care and wit the history of the area, its peculiar ecology and sociology, and the scientific and legislative efforts to save it.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: More a character study than a pro forma thriller, Ripley's Game diverts in large part by finally finding the perfect vehicle for Malkovich's late-period camp ickiness.
Just the sort of not-that -great but not-bad-at-all diversion that cineplexes eternally promise for summer but so often fail to deliver.
A deeply silly movie, but engagingly so.
...A Christmas Day present to the rest of us.
At more than 2- 1/2 hours, Zodiac is like a deep, involving book, a page-turner that you can't put down. You keep reading and, in this case, you keep watching.

Based on the nimbly-written, hilarious, moving and terrifying best-selling Augusten Burroughs memoir, it's a tale that incorporates drug addiction, pedophilia, mental illness, the ordeal of surviving a nightmare childhood.
It's funny and poignant and not for the easily offended.
Chicago 10 is a movie for parents and grandparents to take their older children and grandchildren. It's worth a field trip for high school and college American history classes.
When Ennis del Mar and Jack Twist are together, it's simply about human beings in love. Two men. Now get over it.
Just fasten your seat belt for an undisciplined, unrefined mess. That's a compliment, by the way, on the movie's pleasures and appeal.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Paranoid Park is only 84 minutes, a long, slow 84 minutes, with delusions of grandeur.
Based on the nifty book by Pacific Northwest author Chuck Palahniuk, who also wrote Fight Club, the movie is an examination of obsession, male friendship and mother love.
The Dark Knight is ahead of the curve, dense and demanding, an art film on a grand scale. It won't make you smile, but it will make you ponder this mesmerizing experience.
Alan Moore was right in detaching himself from the project, maintaining his integrity.
The rest of the cast is splendid, including Alec Baldwin, a long way from the network executive on the TV sitcom 30 Rock.
Slumdog Millionaire is a giddy, breathtaking experience, kind of like winning a million bucks. It's also tough, violent and shocking.
It's a credit to the actor that by the end, Langella is living, it seems, in Nixon's skin.

Where did the great hero go, the one from Sean Connery in Goldfinger to Daniel Craig himself in Casino Royale, the elegant killer spy who spews memorable lines, his world-traveling adventures engorged with intrigue and mysterious women?
This superhero saga fizzles.
Quote not available.
Birdwatchers is an unusual and sympathetic exploration of a diminishing society driven to near extinction by capitalism and colonialism. And if it provokes action, then it's a job well done.
movie_title: BirdWatchers - La terra degli uomini rossi (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Aided by a terrific performance from Krisch and an exceptional ensemble cast, Revanche is a beautifully crafted psychological thriller that should firmly place Götz Spielmann on the world cinema map.
Another solid entry in the Denis resume.
Despite the familiar ground, Ralph Ziman manages to orchestrate an engrossing and energetic film full of memorable characters and a wicked soundtrack.
Quote not available.
Leap Year isn't a movie for a sunny afternoon, but Rowe's small tale of sex and despair is a tough trip worth taking.
A slow and sometimes testing parable of sin, faith and redemption, Pavel Lungin's film escapes impenetrable tedium thanks mainly to a captivating central performance.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Kong saan mei yan (An Empress and the Warriors) (The Kingdom and the Beauty) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Means well but ultimately lacks original thrills.
A rewarding experience and a film full of grace, fine performances and a natural, subtle beauty.
A curious concoction of blood, beer, babes and biker ghosts.
A smart and emotionally-driven crime drama.
A gritty, self-assured directorial debut.
Kyle Patrick Alvarez's movie stands out as one the year's as-yet-undiscovered gems.
While Logan Lucky falls strictly into the category of popcorn entertainment, that doesn't make it any less worthy of praise.
Wind River is equal parts beautiful and horrifying, hopeful and heartbreaking.
There is little originality to be found in Wetlands, and despite a few solid performances, very little to otherwise entertain.
Despite its various weaknesses, What Happened to Monday is still weird, wacky fun, a B-movie with a capital B.
Bushwick should have been an exciting and timely response to our nation's difficulties. Instead, it is just plain boring.
6 Days is a mostly well-made film based on true events, but its similarity to our current political climate makes it an uncomfortable watch.
Robespierre and Slate prove with Landline that they are a match made in movie-making heaven, two women who understand that female characters can do unlikable things while still earning our empathy.
Perhaps my expectations of Fighting Belle were misguided, or at the very least too high. Either way, I was disappointed.
The message is important, and Tamarkin delivers it beautifully, but it often feels like it's preaching to the choir.
If you want to be inspired without using your imagination, The Fencer is for you. If you're tired of the same old teacher-related tropes, you'll probably want to skip this one.
If you find yourself thirsty for more Lemonade this summer, find the time to take in a screening of Daughters of the Dust. The trip will open your eyes and your mind.
While Maud's story is powerful, it's the dysfunctional relationship at the center of Maudie - and the it's romanticized - that prevents the film from being truly enjoyable.
Paint It Black features the voices of three very talented women - Tamblyn, Shawkat, and McTeer - and is all the more powerful for it.
Stefan Zweig: Farewell To Europe is a fine display of craftsmanship, but feels a bit too infatuated with its own beauty and intelligence to engage on the level to which it aspires.
Lady Bloodfight is the cinematic equivalent of eating a giant plate of nachos washed down with a cheap beer. Not the highest quality, but you enjoy the experience regardless.
If Rules Don't Apply had focused on just one of its two main storylines, it could have been solid. Instead, it's uneven, lurching between utterly charming and honestly boring.
Fat Camp has good intentions, but its execution doesn't always live up to them. It's a pleasant enough escape from the bombast of blockbusters currently monopolizing cinemas.
Tokyo Idols offers a complex look at a cultural phenomenon that could just as easily have been glossed over as another example of Japanese oddness.
The most powerful - and also the most depressing - thing about Battle of the Sexes is how relevant King's struggle still is today.
To present Tom Of Finland's life in the format of a prestige biopic feels like a poor fit, to say the least.
Our Souls At Night is an important reminder that there are still plenty of stories worth telling in the twilight years of one's life.
It's a particularly disappointing misfire from the man that gave us the low-key masterpiece of Moon, and yet another nail in the coffin of Netflix as a destination for quality original films.

The majority of moviegoers want to see films led by strong, intelligent characters that are more diverse than just heterosexual white men, especially when they are as thoughtfully and beautifully made as this one.

If viewed out of the context of recent events, Rebels on Pointe is an enjoyable and inspirational look inside the world of a unique group of artists that will make you eager to take in one of their performances in real life as soon as possible.
Heavy-handed, predictable and often offensive in its treatment of certain characters, Paradise is a major misfire for Cody.
Despite an admittedly heartwarming message about not putting a price tag on ways to make others happy, there is very little to take away from Almost Paris. You've seen this one before, albeit better.

Molly's Game is a prime showcase for one of Hollywood's most versatile actresses, but the film as a whole doesn't live up to Chastain's fiery performance. A lot is said, but very little sticks with you after the end credits roll.
Diane Kruger carries In the Fade on her leather-clad shoulders and ensures that you'll walk away from the film feeling absolutely rattled.

Proud Mary would be nothing special if it did not star Taraji P. Henson. But it does, and as a result it stands out like a beam of sunshine piercing the dull grey murk that is January at the movies. It is not brilliant, but it is definitely a lot of fun.

I, Tonya takes a sympathetic look at Tonya Harding's life without glossing over the unpleasant parts of her personality; it doesn't try to excuse her bad behavior, but it does try to understand what led her to behave that way in the first place.
Thelma's depiction of the emotional throes one goes through while growing up rings just as true as Greta Gerwig's Lady Bird, even with (or perhaps because of) all the nightmarish trappings.
Knowing how much else Lamarr had to offer, and how little the world cared about it, saddened and infuriated me.
As she does as an actress, Gerwig the director articulates every delicate, emotional nuance. For a debut feature film, it is a triumph.
The combination of dazzlingly detailed production design and Fassbinder's final performance make it hard to tears one's eyes away from the spectacle that is Kamikaze 1989.
The Divine Order is a fierce, fiery film that should be seen by anyone who feels helpless in the ongoing struggle for equality.
Rather than make a statement about class warfare or people living their lives as imposters, Chameleon instead makes a powerful statement as to why we need more women making films about women.
[An] entertaining and empowering ode to the freedom that comes with living an unconventional life.
In a film where the production design has as much dramatic heft as the plot, relentless quirkiness swamps the audience's need to care for and identify with any of the characters.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Harmony Korine's remarkable fifth feature is like nothing the US maverick has ever done -- or anyone else, come to that.
There's enough fang-sinking, tomato sauce and squelchy sound effects to keep us from feeling peckish.
Somehow managing to combine the peppiness of a Doris Day with the sulky intensity of a Noomi Rapace, Deborah Francois is a revelation.
[A] lazy kidnap caper.
This is a mysterious, eerie, experience, whose resistance to easy interpretation (and freewheeling approach to source material) has something of Tarkovsky about it.

Now into their eighties, the Taviani brothers show with this remarkable, fresh and moving drama-documentary they have lost none of that mix of observational rigour and sympathy for the underdog that marked early films like Padre Padrone.

Ninety percent of the success of any good documentary is in the editing, and Philibert is a master of the art, sifting through what one assumes must have been months of footage to give La Maison de la Radio an engaging rhythm and structure.
If buddy-movie Bullet To The Head rolls out just about every cliché in the book, at least it does so with a certain sass and panache.
There's a solid core to this magical realist coming of age tale that smooths over the odd bump.
It's a gripping story that comes in a well-crafted package.

However good your characters and however telling the social and ethical issues your raise, if you ain't got tension, you ain't got a thriller -- and it's in this department that The Company You Keep mostly fails to deliver.
Though it has a certain charm, To Rome With Love is little more than a travel brochure with jokes.

Larrain's bizarre decision to make his film blend in with its extensive passages of archive footage by shooting in U-matic - the default TV production format of the 1980s - makes for an uncomfortable cinematic viewing experience.

[Cronenberg's] dependence on DeLillo's source material means that the director is not entirely his own man, and the atmosphere of impending catastrophe that builds in the course of the film is constantly undermined by its bookish lines and set-ups.
Though it runs at over five hours, there's never a dull moment in this Indian gangland epic by one of India's hottest indie directors, Anurag Kashyap.
If documentaries slotted into feature film genres, this one would be close to horror.
Walter Salles' film is designer Kerouac, a slick product that deploys all the tools of the big-budget, award-chasing indie film.
A committed, thought-provoking documentary.
The film picks up a little when the murder mystery kicks in, but it's only a brief respite.
Sacro Gra's charms have much to do with the director's spot-on selection of a brace of engaging or kooky characters from what must have been dozens of potential candidates.
Although it serves up a few laughs and a couple of set-piece scenes that To completists will want to cut out and keep, Blind Detective is a decidedly minor offering.
Locke is a gripping and deeply cinematic human and ethical drama.
A hugely entertaining mix of film noir, comic buddy movie and meta-cinematic romp.
Even in the midst of the moltovs, Loznitsa's sincere and memorable document retains its fascination with those small details that make us human, and make democracy worth fighting for.
While we respect the message, it feels in the end like a waste of a perfectly good story.
Despite some moments of quirky brilliance and strong performances from Toni Servillo and Alba Rohrwacher, the heart of a TV melodrama beats beneath Dormant Beauty's pale arthouse skin
A powerful, finely scripted issue movie, made all the more incisive by Marion Cotillard's raw performance as a woman fighting to save her job while suffering from depression.
The film doesn't quite get away with its attempt to reconcile satire with pathos, but it comes perilously close.
Scratch the good-looking, emotionally charged surface of James Gray's period take on the love triangle theme he has already explored in Two Lovers and you find a rather stagey melodrama.
A storyline that never quite delivers and some clunky dialogue derail the initial promise of Cinema Paradiso director Giuseppe Tornatore's first English-language feature.
By turns funny, exhilarating and touching, it lacks only one thing: the spiritual and metaphysical depth that made Spirited Away such a haunting experience.

Still a resonant film, a sort of recession-themed cinematic tone poem reminiscent of some of the more out-there cinematic forays of Thai filmmaker Apichatpong Weerasethakul, that keeps on evolving once the pain of the viewing experience has subsided.
Although Out Of The Furnace is done utterly by the book, it also works by the book, delivering a tough, cathartic story straight, no chaser.
Jaco van Dormael's most ambitious film to date is a mess and a miracle at the same time.
David Rosenthal's follow-up to Janie Jones is in the end too shot through with genre cliché to prevail as the gritty thriller that it is striving to be.

The more you delve, the more resonance you find; the problem is that Kiarostami fails to embed the film's visual, aural and symbolic games in a narrative that satisfies on the level of story and character.

Japanese animation genius Hayao Miyazaki's first film for grown-ups - or perhaps that should read 'first film likely to bore the under-tens' - offers plenty of those moments of 2D cine-painting joy and ravishment that we have come to expect.

It's impossible not to acknowledge second-time Greek director Avranas' directorial bravura in making his own firm, cold grasp of his material and story mirror the iron grip of his pater familias antagonist.
Engaging, punchy documentary.

In the end, for all the plot tension and genre tastiness -underlined by some acidic colour photography and lighting that plays up sickly yellows and purples - there's just something a little too mannered about the exercise.
While remaining pretty faithful to the story, Franco somehow manages to inject a note of humour into the story of a man who comes across more as maladroit misfit than evil sociopath.

Wadjda is a well-crafted, liberal and humane message film that will fascinate westerners with its glimpses into the lives of Saudi Arabian women behind closed domestic doors, and stir debate on womens' issues inside and outside the Middle East.
It's a virtuoso piece of filmmaking featuring a magnificently jaded Toni Servillo.
Brandon Cronenberg's feature debut is a cybermedical sci-fi vampire thriller that battles constantly, and with only limited success, against its own ludicrous script.

The Tree Of Life has moments of breathtaking visual and aural beauty, but in the end it has us longing for the days of Badlands, Days Of Heaven or The Thin Red Line, when the Texan auteur also knew how to spin a good yarn.
The film is perhaps too even-handedly in love with the sisterhood it portrays.

To's visual style and soundscapes and the choreography of the film's bullet ballet provide reasons to watch, but the contrived plot, some wooden English dialogue and Hallyday's stilted perfomance derail proceedings well before the final showdown.

Although it feels at times like a vanity project, some strong performances - most notably by Spanish actress Maribel Verdu, but also Vincent Gallo in the title role and newcomer Alden Ehrenreich - save all but Tetro's most cringeworthy lines.
It's one of those films whose appeal grows post-screening. Fluently shot with frequent but not jerky handheld camera shots and engagingly edited, Empty Nest is discreetly stylish.
A smart urban screwball comedy about the perils of idiocy that uses its all-star cast to dazzling and often hilarious effect.

Some of the scenes in this gentle romantic pickpocketing yarn are pure cinematic pleasure, but in the end the plot and the characters are too thin to turn a series of delightfully stylised setpieces into a fully satisfying film.

This is not a rock tour film for CSNY fans so much as a rambling, occasionally thought-provoking, sometimes moving enquiry into the question of whether the sixties protest music generation has lost its leverage over hearts and minds.
A charming indie title, suffused with the spirit of the French New Wave of the early sixties and possessed of a quirky likeability.

Moretti's performance -- unusually for an actor whose chief trait is sardonic superiority - mines a vein of self-doubt and frail desperation that, together with his tender relationship with his daughter, gives Quiet Chaos a broad human touch.
Having hooked us with the tagline, director Henry Bean never seems to be sure quite where to run with it.
Thorn In The Heart reads like an honest, considered portrait of a remarkable woman, but it's not much more than an amuse-bouche for Gondry fans.
If the director never quite gets to the heart of the man, that's part of his point: Andreotti emerges from the film as a collection of fragments.

[The film] has a kooky, laid back charm and is full of Anderson's trademark themes and surreal eye candy, but ultimately, for all its offbeat wit and road-to-enlightenment send-ups, it feels a little thin.

One of the nice things about Schnabel's film is the way it transmits the energy of one of those concerts where everything comes together. Even impassive, stern Lou himself is wearing a huge smile on his face by the end.
An uncompromising experiment in how much suffering a soul can take, both on screen and in one's cinema seat.
Smoky grey backgrounds add layering and depth, while silhouette-work and jerky cardboard-puppet sequences nod humorously at the Arabian Nights tradition.
An original and even memorable addition to Van Sant's filmography.
Harrowing but limpidly shot.
It may not be subtle, but it makes for great, heart-on-sleeve cinema.
Delpy and her co-star Adam Goldberg make a pitch for the talky, neurosis-ridden wit and pace of vintage Woody Allen, and most of the time they hit the spot.
There's good buddy chemistry between Koo and Chan, and although some sloppily-shot bridging scenes betray the hectic schedules of Hong Kong cinema, the key action sequences look just fine.
Those who are prepared to forgive the film its stock characters and lack of emotional subtlety may allow themselves to be ravished -- by the sumptuous soundtrack, if nothing else.
Rust And Bone is a big film in every sense, sure-footed, stylish and confident, that mainlines emotion into its audience.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A moving dramatic fable about an elderly airport janitor's relationship with a bunch of Amman street kids.
Fashion designer Tom Ford gets it spectacularly right first time round in his directorial debut.
Limp and bloodless.
With Killer Joe, a black comedy thriller adapted from a play by Tracy Letts, Friedkin seems to have recaptured some of that youthful energy.
Celebrates an old-fashioned, underrated cinematic pleasure: the chance to see an ensemble cast of fine actors sparring with each other, and at the top of their game.
Grittily real but somehow dreamlike at the same time, coming of age tale Corpo Celeste is a quietly impressive feature debut for documentary maker Alice Rohrwacher.
For all the film's command of dark fairy-tale atmosphere it's such a long and sluggish haul that many in the audience will find themselves cheering on the apocalypse.
Celine Sciamma's third film has all the quiet determination and punchy life force of its magnetic 16-year-old heroine.

The film's greatest strength though is the way it combines hints that we're watching a parable of the new US climate of anxiety with an unflinching dedication to the reality of its characters' plights.

A delightfully underplayed turn from Michel Piccoli as a newly-elected Pope paralysed by feelings of inadequacy, a large dose of widescreen confidence and some moments of delicate human observation fail to make up for the unresolved feel.

Once the Seven-Samurai-style band of brothers is assembled, 13 Assassins is pure pleasure: and it culminates in a magnificent 45-minute showdown that has to be the best final battle sequence in cinema since, oh, Kill Bill at least.

Though it's a likeable story with a decent pop-psychology twist, the big dramatic problem with The Hole is the way its cute atmosphere and Disney-style teen bonding sessions and scary, thriller elements keep cancelling each other out.
One of the most remarkable Iranian films to surface in the last few years, About Elly is a small but compelling ensemble piece of surprising depth.
There's a tasty idea in here, and it's entertainingly executed: graft a detective story onto a historical martial arts actioner set during the Tang dynasty, and see what emerges.
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: One of the delights of the film is the way it dramatises the house from a three-inch perspective.
Fiennes fully rises to the challenge of the role: petulant, brave, arrogant, loyal only (to an almost homoerotic extent) to fellow soldiers, but fatally in thrall to his stronger mother.
Though the film and its director undoubtedly have a great deal of heart and passion, too many scenes feel like actors' workshop exercises.
Rarely has dance been used in film with such narrative thrust and verve, and rarely have the strains of dramatic performance been so intriguingly unpicked.
Arthouse audiences will find themselves dipping in and out of engagement but the story is too contrived in the long run to resonate much beyond its own four walls.
movie_title: The Milk of Sorrow (La Teta Asustada) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Rwandan genocide of 1994 has spawned a number of feature films, but Anne Aghion's remarkable documentary about the 'Gacaca' community tribunals is the most calmly moving guide yet to the emotional landscape of those who were left behind.
Probably the most authentic and unsentimental mafia movie ever to come out of Italy.
