Albert Nobbs is a first-rate film in every respect. This should come as no surprise to anyone who has followed the work of director Rodrigo Garcia, one of the most talented-and underrated-filmmakers working today.
My problem with Man on a Ledge is that once I understood the real storyline-the one hidden behind the flashy premise-I became impatient to see it resolved.

To say that this is not an easy film to watch is putting it mildly. No one would deny Tilda Swinton's superior performance, but people were sharply divided when We Need to Talk About Kevin screened at the Telluride Film Festival last fall.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The primary hero, on screen and off, is Ralph Fiennes, who not only makes a formidable directing debut but delivers a ferocious (and commanding) performance in the leading role.
...the cure for Oskar's severe case of shell-shock, in Eric Roth's adaptation of the novel by Jonathan Safran Foer, seems artificial and contrived to me.
Steven Soderbergh's Haywire has all the trappings of an "A" movie, including a big-name cast and impressive international locations, but it never rises above the level of a "B."
The story of the Tuskegee Airmen is one that every American should know, and deserving of a great film; unfortunately, this isn't it.

It takes the combined personalities of Queen Latifah and Dolly Parton to wring entertainment value out of Joyful Noise, which they do to some degree, but it's the lively choral music performances that partially salvage this kettle of corn.
What keeps The Iron Lady afloat is the mesmerizing work of its star. As we already know, Streep goes beyond mimicry to fully inhabit her characters, from The French Lieutenant's Woman to Julia Child.
If ever there were a typical January movie, it's Contraband, a film so dreary (and downright distasteful) that no studio would think of releasing it in December, when all eyes are focused on quality.
First-time feature filmmaker Dee Rees has crafted a movie that is consistently riveting because it is steeped in truth. She and her cast never once strike a false note.
What keeps The Iron Lady afloat is the mesmerizing work of its star. As we already know, Streep goes beyond mimicry to fully inhabit her characters...
There are no heroes or villains in this story: there are only everyday figures who try their best and struggle to survive.

The production is still needlessly overlong and overblown, a far cry from your father's (or even your cousin's) conception of the master detective. But it's certainly lively and has clever moments that involve Holmes' keen powers of observation...
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are some striking moments-...bloody battles in which people are speared, beheaded, or pulverized-but there is no overarching visual concept that is worthy of the director's reputation. We might as well be watching Clash of the Titans.
To my mind, Melancholia is both absorbing and absurd. It opens with a visual prologue that turns out to be a précis of the film that is to follow.

I've seen great caper movies, and this isn't one of them. As mainstream Hollywood studio movies go, Tower Heist isn't bad, and it will probably fulfill most audience's desire for escapist fare. But despite some good laughs...
It should be no shock that the film is intelligent and well-made, considering the source material... What's somewhat surprising is how engrossing a story about the business side of baseball can be...

Restless has some touching moments as the two loners realize they're falling in love, but it threatens to suffocate in its own quaintness. It's only natural for teenagers to see life in outsized proportions...
For me, Drive is all attitude, punctuated by unpleasant bursts of violence. If that's what passes for cutting-edge filmmaking, or storytelling, we're in trouble.

I can't call Contagion as a feel-good movie. In fact, you won't want to be feeling anything-or anyone-after seeing this cautionary tale about the spread of a deadly virus. But you won't be able to take your eyes off the screen...
Following his impressive feature debut, Sin Nombre, director Cary Fukunaga has brought his keen eye and humanistic sensibilities to this oft-told story.

Win Win isn't a morality play; it's just a really good story. But it does deal with an issue that couldn't be more relevant: Where do we draw the line when it comes to survival if it means clouding our sense of right and wrong?
The bemused smile on his face may fool some people into believing he doesn't have a strong point of view, but he does: like the man from Michigan, Spurlock is a muckraker...
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Debt has occasional moments of suspense, but the human element of the story-including a romantic rivalry-plays out in clunky, heavy-handed fashion. By the time we get to the modern-day climax it's hard to care...

That Vera Farmiga gives an honest, empathetic performance should come as no surprise; she is one of the most gifted and daring actresses of our time, as she's proved in such films as Down to the Bone, Breaking and Entering, and Up in the Air...

Sometimes one can admire a film without truly liking it; that's how I feel about the ambitious British remake of Brighton Rock. Graham Greene's 1938 novel, first filmed in the late 1940s, has been cleverly reworked...

The key decision in a film like this is how soon to reveal the monsters, and how clearly to show them. Usually the more you see them the less terrifying they get to be, although these rodent-like creatures remain pretty fearsome...
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I came to this film knowing nothing about it, except that it was based on the highly-acclaimed novel by Kazuo Ishiguru. I had no foreknowledge of its story or premise-and I'm glad...

Amigo ought to be a great film: the subject is fascinating and still resonates today, even though it takes place over a hundred years ago. The Philippine-American war has been pretty much ignored...

You don't go to a movie like this expecting to hear Shakespearean dialogue, but the action, under Marcus Nispel's direction, is consistently vigorous and exciting. So are the visual effects, from an epic battle with sand creatures to a...

As with a good live-action movie, it all begins with the script, and this one is solid-well thought-out, briskly paced, funny and sweet. In the end, it's the finished film that matters, not the process...

In theory, I suppose it would be funny-and incongruous-if in the middle of a serious costume drama a noble action hero uttered a four-letter word. Hearing Danny McBride do just that, repeatedly, in Your Highness not only isn't funny but grows wearisome...

What can I say about a movie that made me want to take a shower and cleanse myself afterward? 30 Minutes or Less is so shallow, self-satisfied, and downright repulsive that I hesitate to discuss it at all...

If you lived through that time, it is incredible to contemplate how much has changed (and how much hasn't) over the years, not only in race relations but in attitudes toward women. That's part of the fascination of watching The Help...
Karen Janszen and Noam Dromi have built a screenplay around a true story that draws on familiar Hollywood-movie tropes, but plays well just the same...

What I responded to was the cleverness of the parody, which far exceeds a one-joke idea, its expert execution (especially for a first-time feature-film director) and the wonderful performances of its two leading actors, Alan Tudyk and Tyler Labine.

...it's a pretty neat trick to blend comedy with a story that's moving and relevant; it helps to have a smart screenplay, a strong cast, and an overall good vibe. Those qualities make 50/50 one of the bright spots on the fall movie map...
As someone who-swimming against the tide-didn't care for Bridesmaids, imagine my surprise to find another female-driven, female-written R-rated comedy so entertaining.

The moment that Puss made his debut in Shrek 2, dramatically voiced by Antonio Banderas, and all but walked away with the picture, it was clear that DreamWorks Animation had created a resonant character.

I'm delighted to see that the Weinstein Company is re-releasing one of the year's most overlooked films, Sarah's Key, the moving adaptation of Tatiana De Rosnay's international best-seller. It's one of the year's best films.

Hollywood has given a black eye to the romantic comedy; romantic dramas are scarce. All the more reason to cheer Drake Doremus' fresh, vibrant film Like Crazy, which is anything but a conventional genre piece.
There are great moments in Anonymous, from its arresting opening scene ... to recreations of the first performances ever given of Henry V and Hamlet before a spellbound throng of groundlings...
The concept is mildly interesting at first-even the cops are called timekeepers-but the novelty wears off pretty fast...
This is a film that depends more on tone and atmosphere than narrative strength. It won't be to everybody's taste, but I found it diverting and easy to take.

Just when you were about to give up on 3-D-and the inflated price of admission to watch it on a theater screen-along comes a film that's worth the money. In fact, it isn't the story that makes Puss in Boots stand out, but the imaginative staging...
If the story outline seems simple, it is; this movie is all about attitude and style. The shabby-genteel hero, who has a keen sense of irony, and the people who help him...
Margin Call manages to put a human face on the current economic crisis-but I wish it was as good as its trailer, which is forceful, well-edited, and dramatically scored...
How often have we seen well-intentioned movies become sanctimonious and lose their dramatic edge? No such accusations can be leveled at Jim Loach's Oranges and Sunshine, an impressive film that...

We all know about good intentions and where they can lead. No one could question the serious intent of The Whistleblower or the scandalous behavior it reveals on the part of so-called United Nations peacekeepers in Bosnia during the late 1990s...
Even if it had nothing else to offer, Martha Marcy May Marlene would be worth seeing to witness the debut of an extraordinary young actress, Elizabeth Olsen...
From the billboards you might think this is another Transformers movie-heaven help us-when in fact, Real Steel is a cross between Rocky and The Champ.

The world of politics provides all the drama-and satiric fodder-any filmmaker could ask for. And even though the public has shown indifference to such movies in recent years, Hollywood keeps making them...
Nothing Almodóvar does could be without interest, and this is no exception: his production design and attention to detail are formidable, and he is in perfect harmony with his actors.

...the film itself qualifies as a rara avis: a benign, good-hearted movie about three disparate characters' search for happiness. The fact that it's rated PG, and yet is intended for adult audiences, should tell you something about the movie's nature.

This is a situation where audiences will go into the theater humming the featured songs, and while the movie they see offers no surprises, it does something relatively few fall releases can claim: it delivers exactly what it promises...
The Ides of March has star-power on its side, with Clooney and Gosling in the leads, but even if people are attracted to theaters by their presence they're not likely to leave feeling satisfied...

I like films that reveal themselves gradually, instead of following an instantly predictable pattern. That's one reason I was so taken with Philippe Le Guay's The Women on the 6th Floor. On the surface it's a social comedy...
movie_title: Les femmes du 6e étage (The Women on the 6th Floor) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Real Steel is a cross between Rocky and The Champ. It's formulaic and unashamedly manipulative, but it's played with sincerity...and it works...
If you're looking for some kind of poetry-some exalted dramatic arc that lifts this narrative out of the ordinary-you won't find it here. Contagion is...gripping from start to finish.
Take Shelter is a provocative original from writer-director Jeff Nichols, built on the foundation of a searing performance by Michael Shannon. It's a film I respect...
There couldn't be a more serious subject, yet Gordon-Levitt and especially Rogen (who co-produced the movie) make the comedy seem both spontaneous and organic.
With so many dramas depicting the varied facets of life in war-torn Middle Eastern countries, none are quite like this intimate depiction of a young woman's existence in The Patience Stone.
I've become gun-shy about trusting any film that's telling a true story, so I don't know how accurate 42 is... but it does hit the essential points of a great American saga.
Wong Kar Wai's new epic The Grandmaster is an exquisite-looking film and leading man, Tony Leung, is a quietly compelling presence in it.
A bit formulaic? Perhaps. Still... a lot to like here for Bridget Jones's fans, including Dempsey, who slips into the role of another suitor with charm and aplomb...
Stone's Snowden comes off especially tame... familiar ground with nothing of note revealed... unusual given the filmmaker's past undertakings.
Krasinski has fashioned one of the better films to view this summer, underscored by the performances of a dream cast...
An absorbing visual treatise on technology and the internet... Documentarian Herzog explores the effect on individual lives to the interconnectedness of the planet.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ben-Hur plays out, far from a modern day classic, but as spirited summer fare for an entertaining afternoon at the movies....
Stop-motion animation touches the next stage of excellence in Kubo. It all works: storytelling, direction, voice talent... the totality of artistry...
A Disney vehicle that swoops in to fill us with a sense of wonder. .. Filmmaker Lowery has helmed a joyful re-imagining destined to be the delight of the summer...
Streep is splendid in the titular role ... Grant is witty and nuanced, never hitting a false note, as her devoted husband and partner...
Richard Linklater's dreams are reflected on, in an examination of a singular filmmaker as independent as he is commercial.
Taken from a popular DC comic series... helmed by a star quality director... peppered with a highly skilled, all-star cast ... What could go wrong? Nearly everything.
Action sequences-way too familiar-mixed with a plot-far too transparent-yields a not very exciting Bourne...

Filmmaker Birbiglia has created his Annie Hall here... Funny, artfully entertaining and with widespread appeal... Don't Think Twice is the perfect movie for anyone on the hunt for a summer movie treat.
Production Designer Santo Loquasto produced an exquisite 1930's Hollywood and New York City; one of the best things about this latest Allen cinematic entree...
A Ghostbuster team worth calling... this one's a comedic win...
Watching Crowe and Gosling-who are admittedly enjoying themselves in their respective roles-is fun, but the road wears thin along the journey...
'Neighbors 2' surprises by mixing serious undertones in with the fun-stuff... Talents of Rogen and Byrne up the grade of this comedic follow-up.
Documenting the inner life of creative artists and their world is challenging at best... 'Genius' manages to capture the grandiose dreams of both infamous writer, Wolfe, and his long-fabled editor...
An emotionally powerful docudrama which shows an unexpected connectedness to Disney.
Told with intimacy and candor and a no holds barred approach, 'Roseanne for President!' is a winner.
A, tale-of-the-times, typical family living an atypical life... Mortensen is more than spot-on perfect for the role... kids and supporting players are terrific.
Lots of fun stuff in this kiddie-pleasing film full of appealing characters... A good story jarred by frenetic pacing
A radiant Lily Rabe is a stand out in this diverting movie fare...
Spielberg has brought together two exceptionally talented performers: a veteran and a newcomer; not the only stand outs in this otherworldly fantasy tale...
Truth be told, London Road, is a musical unlike any other and lead Olivia Coleman is a first-rate artistic chameleon worthy of being noticed...
Whether we're talking about fictional filmmaking or documentaries, Tower is one of the best films of the year.
Genuinely exciting chases and action scenes as well as a talented supporting cast can't save this film. It's a shame the effort that went into it doesn't pay off
I wanted to be swept up in the emotions of the piece but I never was. I cry easily at movies, yet this one kept me at a distance, perhaps because it covers such familiar ground
I was not expecting to enjoy this film, but I have to admit, Why Him? is likeable and funny. While the film isn't destined to be a critical darling, it succeeded in making me laugh
Scorsese has given us a rare and extraordinary gift. Silence transported me to another time and place and gave me great empathy for its leading characters. It is the pinnacle of personal filmmaking
It's hard not to respond with tears seeing how individuals-and a community-faced with tragedy pull their lives back together. I found it humbling. Patriots Day packs an emotional wallop
This movie runs just under two hours and its resolution, which comes with surprising abruptness, leaves us wanting. Star power and cool sets cannot support a movie without a good third act.

Some animated features have staying power as parents can confirm from the number of times their kids want to revisit the movies at home. This slick production, directed by Garth Jennings, is more like fast food-easily digested and just as easily forgotten
Electrifying performances from Denzel Washington, Viola Davis and a stunning cast-enacting one of the great 20th century American plays-make Fences a must-see
Neruda offers a captivating and unusual approach to a famous person's life. I know little about the poet but I fell under this movie's sway

Jackie begins at a fever pitch and never lets up. What Noah Oppenheim's dazzling screenplay & Pablo Lorrain's direction manage to thrust us back in time and make us see a series of historical events in a way we never have before

What do you call a movie that has a great first act and a moving finale but bogs down on the way to that conclusion? In this case, you call it Lion. I say this with regret, because the true story it tells is remarkable and it's a shame the film is flawed

Elle is an outrageous mix of psychological thriller and character study in which that character is a mass of contradictions. Only an actress as skillful as Huppert could play her to the hilt and not repel us
Tom Ford masters this tricky narrative by establishing two separate, completely tangible environments. What's more, he maintains a consistent tone for both facets of this seductive story
This is without question my favorite film of the year
Is a portrait of life written with cut-to-the-bone honesty. That's what makes Moonlight so arresting
My reaction to this movie is mixed, at best.

It's a film you'll want to discuss and debate with your friends. The message may not be original but the methodology certainly is. A movie doesn't have to spell everything out for me if I get a sense that the filmmaker is offering me something to ponder
Bravo to Warren Beatty for making an original and highly pleasing piece of entertainment.

The drama is low-key and the issues far from extraordinary, but the characters are real and recognizable. What's more, they are brought to life by talented actresses who understand Reichardt's less-is-more approach to storytelling.
The film doesn't pretend to offer answers or solutions, nor is it a cautionary tale: it is a straightforward dramatization of this unfortunate woman's life and it is spine-tinglingly good.
Director Gavin O'Connor handles all of this efficiently but the protracted screenplay and unlikely story twists do him no favors. We're left with a cluttered, unsatisfying mess.
Even a phalanx of good actors can't save this-less than-Magnificent Seven...

As expected, 'Alice' is a visual extravaganza-at times eye-popping. So much to take in, it borders on exhausting. Still James Bobin and his team have created an environment which is a pleasure to behold...

Arguably, no one knows the 'X-Men' saga like Bryan Singer and his stalwart production team, which is evident when playing with characters and timelines, as they've done in the past, and do so expertly here.
'Finding Dory' in the wake its predecessor, the now-legendary 'Nemo,' was no small task... delightfully pleasing on every level...
This one rewards the viewer with a typically fine performance by Rebecca Hall and a revelatory one by Jason Sudeikis, whom we usually associate with comedy.
Hail, Caesar! ... a slice of Hollywood fluff.
Walking out of Zoolander 2 was the obvious choice...
It's never a bad time for a good western and Bone Tomahawk is a good western...
Tarantino. Unarguably a gifted filmmaker. Probably why no one said "enough."
Joy's "inspired by" story doesn't bore and yet there's not much to cheer about...
Smith's talent and presence holds true... familiar tale loses a bit of its dramatic punch...
Award-time musings for DiCaprio notwithstanding, 'The Revenant' remains adrift in the snow...
Rampling shines in this nuanced study on commitment and bonds in relationships...
'Star Wars' comes full circle... the cherished familiar interlaced with hints of more to come...
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Documentarian Stig Björkman has sifted through a hefty amount of material to construct a telling portrait of an intriguing star.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Caine, superb as always, is back at work in this sublimely visual treatise on...
A hard, often confusing, look at what occurred during the 2008 financial meltdown...
Excellent cast and overwhelming special effects are provided aplenty, however...
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [An] extraordinary and unprecedented film.
Hooper's keen direction is only amplified by two extraordinary performances...
Director Haynes unfurls this love story in the shadows with a delicate hand.
Perfect holiday treat for the kids with great characters and majestically rendered landscapes.
A familiar story that speaks to people of any age...'Creed' is fulfilling, crowd-pleasing, entertainment...
Filmmaker Billy Ray scores a bull's-eye with this remake of the Argentinian Oscar winner.
Despite exhilarating special effects and action sequences, Katniss meets her waterloo in 'Mockingjay' Part 2
Moore's works, more advocacy than documentary in their approach, impel the viewer to take note or even better action.
Kung Pow! for Kung Fu Panda 3. The third in the series is all that!
Finest Hours is action and adventure on a grand scale.
Usually Jane Austen is indestructible, but in this case... not so much.
Well told tale, equal parts compelling and derailing... Adds credence to the Twain saying: truth is stranger than...
It is not unusual, after viewing one of Jacques Audiard's films, to come away with a sensation of having observed true intimacy in an authentic world.
Essential elements are there for Money Monster to be more than just good: skillful direction, whiplash editing, and up to the mark performances... and yet...
Dough is a sweet, feel-good film.
Big, Bigger and Biggest doesn't equal Best in this Captain America chapter of the Avengers movie chronicle.
The supporting cast is first-rate, and it's great to see Susan Sarandon in a leading role that makes such good use of her talent.
In Sing Street, filmmaker John Carney provides a wholly charming, delightful, amusingly familiar passage of life.
Favreau's reinvention of a beloved '60s classic... delightfully entertaining... bordering on perfection...
Melissa McCarthy is an unqualified talent. Unfortunately, The Boss is a near-miss...
Demolition doesn't suffer from Vallée's fine direction or Gyllenhaal's outstanding performance...
Ultimately, the value of 20th Century Women is that it provides Annette Bening with a prime showcase. It's worth seeing just to watch her grapple with this challenging character
After the delight of the first film... what happened here? Too big, too noisy, too obvious...
Astute look at working class people... Compassionately executed...
A touching portrait of a woman with a dream... leading lady, Catherine Frot, is perfection.
Profound examination of the psychic ramifications involving modern day warfare and long-range gun-play.
Inspired by a promise made... Remember is a potent thriller replete with big surprises.
Doris ...slightly uneven in tempo and tone... while Ms. Field remains at the top of her game and as likable as ever.
A bit formulaic, but oh so scary. Then there's John Goodman!
Hollywood disaster movie genre executed Scandinavian style...
Disarming characters... multidimensional plot form the core of an atypical Disney movie that's right on the mark...
A War pays service to all sides: Danish soldiers, Afghan inhabitants, and the families... Straightforward and absorbing storytelling...
Embracing such concepts as the liquidity of time, Serpent honors the Amazonian world and culture, while condemning those that would harm it.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A science fiction tale on a human scale... Jeff Nichols' follow up to Mud confirms the singularity of this filmmaker.
"Spotlight" is terrific... and certainly ranks as one of the best films of the year!

This film is designed to rouse an audience, and I can't see how it can fail to do so. The heroines of this tale are both admirable and likable, what the movie may lack in nuance it makes up for in good will
Julieta may not be one of Almodóvar's best efforts but it is still quite good, and that's no insult. It's a haunting story that's well worth seeing

It's a pleasure to watch Bryan Cranston, Steve Carell and Laurence Fishburne. Richard Linklater may be known for his vivid portraits of youth, but here he tackles an equally daunting subject with considerable success: manhood.
Griffin Dunne's exemplary film has made me want to dive into Joan Didion's work; that's the highest compliment I could pay any documentary
movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's no use beating about the bush: I really didn't like this movie. It tries to embrace both social satire and black comedy but its tone is strangely somber and its approach heavy-handed.
Novitiate is a solid and nuanced drama that enables us to experience a world most of us know little or nothing about.

This is a sly social satire that demands patience from its audience, but like last year's Toni Erdmann, there are ample rewards for those who stay the course. I wish The Square was shorter, but its major set pieces are brilliant.

Only the Brave is not a hollow Hollywood action movie: it's a tribute to a group of men, and their supportive women, who made a difference. Watching the film is a humbling and intensely moving experience.
I found this film absolutely mesmerizing. If you're any kind of film buff, 78/52 is a must-see.
This is a muddled adaptation of Jo Nesbø's best-selling thriller. I'm hard pressed to remember another police procedural that was so dull, or so encumbered in trying to tell its story.
It's always discouraging when I don't care for a film that was clearly a labor of love for the talented people involved. I was anticipating an emotional and immersive experience and didn't get it.
I don't need a thesaurus to describe my reaction to Faces Places. I can sum it up in two words: pure pleasure.
There's no denying that this is fascinating material, the kind you couldn't and wouldn't make up--Writer-director Angela Robinson has taken on a formidable challenge in telling this story
I kept hoping that Marshall would take off and soar, which it never quite does... but it tells its story well.
I loved this movie from the moment it started. Writer-director Noah Baumbach hits many resonant notes in this perceptive screenplay about a dysfunctional family.

In the hands of these skillful filmmakers and a well-chosen cast, Goodbye, Christopher Robin tells a bittersweet story grounded in truth. Its handsome production may be genteel but it's far from bland.
The Florida Project is one of this year's best films, a remarkable slice of life. If ever there were a sleeper deserving of wide recognition, this is it.

I admire the hard work that went into this film by a team of people who are devotees of the original and strove to do it justice. Fans and admirers will weigh in en masse, I'm sure...but I found Blade Runner 2049 long and boring.

American Made gives director Doug Liman and charismatic star Tom Cruise a superior vehicle and plays to their strengths. It's a solid piece of entertainment that takes a stranger-than-fiction story and brings it to life in convincing fashion.

Lucky is a remarkable film, a living testament to the talent and formidable screen presence of the late Harry Dean Stanton. I think we are the lucky ones to have such a beautiful film to remember the actor by.

The screenplay unfolds in unhurried fashion, allowing us to spend quality time with two highly watchable movie stars. This is the allure of Our Souls at Night and anyone who thinks of that as a pleasurable experience will not be disappointed
Watching Dame Judi is a sheer delight, indeed a privilege, and is surrounded by a cast befitting her presence. Let the nay-sayers carp as they will: I thoroughly enjoyed Victoria & Abdul.

The movie also suffers the disappointment that comes with any sequel: the novelty is gone. For Matthew Vaughn, too much is never enough. Excess, hand-in-hand with bad taste, marks most of his films, even when they're entertaining.

It isn't every day you see a film so attuned to the outsized drama of adolescent life. The film is bursting with life and rich in observations both large and small. Kudos to Gerwig and all of her collaborators
I don't want to invest another minute of my time thinking about Mother! I respect Aronofsky's gutsiness, and Lawrence's as well, but I found the movie to be an ordeal. All I want is to move on.

Marvel is too smart to completely undermine the serious matters at stake for its stable of characters, but confident enough to play with them a bit. Thor Ragnarok has a personality all its own, and I suspect Marvel fans will love every minute.
The filmisn't perfect, and with so many details and characters-bordering on the edge of clutter-is ripe for nit-picking. But on the whole I had a good time.
The World's End is out to give its audience a good time, which the cast seems to be having from start to finish.

I wouldn't presume to guess how a 12-year-old will respond to this film, especially if that girl or boy hasn't read Madeleine L'Engle's beloved book. I can only express my feelings, which are decidedly mixed.
The Death of Stalin is a breath of fresh air and a genuinely great screen comedy. Iannucci conducts the proceedings like the conductor of a great orchestra with an array of virtuosos at his command.

I left Red Sparrow with no sense of satisfaction. I'm not sure what the takeaway is supposed to be. I'd prefer to get these messages in a movie that didn't make me feel as if I, too, had been victimized.
Early Man may not have the punch or pizzazz of a mainstream Hollywood cartoon feature, but it has a tangible charm all its own. As a fan, I wouldn't have it any other way.

Black Panther is, culturally and commercially, the right film at the right time. The significance of bringing a black superhero to the screen at this moment cannot be overstated. Any reservations I have will, and possibly should, fall by the wayside
This is well-made entertainment, pure and simple, with enough surprises along the way to avoid being strictly formulaic. What's more, it accomplishes all this in just under an hour and a half.
Chastain is always worth watching, and so is Elba, but I wanted more from this film, and Molly's Game left me dissatisfied.
Downsizing is one of my favorite films this year. I am an unabashed admirer of Alexander Payne and his writing partner Jim Taylor, because they deal in a commodity that's all too rare: social satire

Depicting obsession is a trap for any filmmaker. He or she defies the audience to remain interested in someone whose behavior is abnormal. Having Daniel Day-Lewis portraying the character is an enormous asset, but it may not be enough. It wasn't for me.

There is never a bad time to be reminded of the importance of a free press, but Steven Spielberg has seized this moment and made it count. The result is mainstream moviemaking at its very best: intelligent and entertaining

If you're still not convinced that Margot Robbie is more than just a beauty,I, Tonyashould do the trick. I couldn't take my eyes from the screen. Cheers to everyone who collaborated on this first-rate film...and a deep bow to Margot Robbie.

That's what's missing from the movie: pleasure. Allen is apparently trying to channel Eugene O'Neill in his portrayal of this forlorn family, but Wonder Wheel is no Long Day's Journey Into Night. It's not even long; it just feels that way

The Shape of Water rekindles a sense of wide-eyed wonder that's all too rare in contemporary cinema. Computer imagery can create amazing sights, but only a master moviemaker (and movie lover) could have fashioned this dazzling, one-of-a-kind experience.
American families deserve to see this excellent film.The Breadwinneris a visually striking feature with a relatable young heroine; it is as fresh and relevant as any movie of 2017

If Bombshell inspires people to seek out her movies, it will have achieved two goals: giving her the belated credit she deserves for a critical invention, and laying the groundwork to rebuild her reputation as an actress. Her beauty speaks for itself.

This is heartwarming family fare for this holiday season: not a mindless piece of fluff but an intriguing story about a man whose work continues to resonate with readers (and filmgoers) around the world.

This ambitious film takes what we know as history and captures the immediacy and uncertainty of that fateful period. But the real strength ofDarkest Hour-and the reason it must be seen-is Gary Oldman.

Pixar movies always look good, butCocois in a class by itself. Ablaze with eye-popping color, every widescreen frame is filled with richly detailed settings and appealing characters. This film is truly a celebration
The slogan "choose kind" is not just a tagline; it's a byword for our times and I wish more movies would preach that message. Wonderis a beautiful movie.
Mudboundis easy to admire but tough to watch at times. It tells a truthful tale from America's not-so-distant past. The highest compliment I can pay Rees is that her movie feels truthful.

You never know what to expect from Martin McDonough, and that's one reason this film is so striking. He offers a consistently off-kilter view of human behavior, brought to life by a first-rate ensemble cast

Home Again is comedy in the comfort zone. Rather than cite all the things this movie doesn't have-I'd rather compliment Meyers-Shyer old-fashioned Hollywood movie that chooses to swim against the tide of the moment
The only thing this film kills is time. I didn't believe a single moment and that's a shame because it arrives in theaters with a solid pedigree.

A deeply-felt adaptation of journalist Jeannette Walls's best-selling memoir about growing up with impoverished and irresponsible parents. An emotional high-wire act like this is tough for any movie to take on, the results are less than perfect.
Nothing is as individual or personal as the grieving process, which is why Polonsky's debut feature is so effective. The film was made in Israel but its emotional content is universal.
movie_title: One Week and a Day (Shavua ve Yom) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You don't have to be a movie buff to fall in love with the story of Harold and Lillian Michelson. Their sixty-year marriage-with more than its share of ups and downs-would be compelling. Their long involvement with Hollywood is icing on the cake
movie_title: Harold And Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This has been a rich year for jazz-related documentaries. That happy trend continues with Chasing Trane.
movie_title: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary (2017)

movie_review_blurb: After more than two hours of logic-defying sights and sounds and two-dimensional characters, I was happy to see the movie come to an end. I fear the series will just keep going and going. No one cares what any critic has to say about a movie like this

I couldn't have anticipated that Swedish filmmaker Kasper Collin would provide such a personal and moving portrait of the musician, who died at age 33. You don't have to love jazz to be drawn into this remarkable story

It's never a waste of time watching Jessica Chastain, even if the film she's in isn't great. This is an earnest historical drama that never scales the emotional heights the real-life story would seem to promise. But Chastain is faultless

Life will give moviegoers the tremors and jolts they desire as it adds a notch to the résumé of its writers and director. But truth be told, it remains in the shadow of Alien, a tough movie to top, let alone equal

Unlike some contrived or cynical rehashes of old TV series, this one has no pretensions. It's escapism with a capital E: a funny, energetic, enjoyably ragged buddy movie with lots and lots of car-chase action

Beauty and the Beast is better than I expected it to be. I still don't understand why Disney insists on recycling its most popular and beloved movies, but when the public repeatedly responds with box-office dollars it's hard to argue

This is the best monster movie I've seen in years, adding new energy and excitement to a storyline that incorporates the ingredients we all expect. It's been too long since I had such fun at a movie that promises just that
Fans of Marvel, X-Men, and the Wolverine character should be pleased with Logan-it's a strong finale and arguably the best in this highly uneven spin-off series.

You may be reminded of other creepy movies like Rosemary's Baby and The Stepford Wives, but this is neither a retread nor a spoof. It's a rare, seamless blend of horror and comedy: a stinging satire cloaked as a thriller.
'I Don't Feel At Home in This World Anymore' is a vigilante story turned upside down and played as a violent farce. The characters and situations are believable enough to keep us engaged
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: 'My Life as a Zucchini' shows us the true meaning of kindness and empathy. It is a tonic in the harsh world we all inhabit. The film is charming and different from most American animated features
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: 'Kedi' is steeped in charm and simple wisdom. I should state flat-out that I am not a cat person, but this film won me over all the same

Land of Mine, which overseas bears the title Under the Sand, is a provocative drama that poses timeless questions. It's easy to see why Academy voters chose it as a contender for this year's Best Foreign Language Film Oscar.
The Space Between Us bears faint echoes of other outer-space sagas but carves its own niche because its hero is a teenage boy. It's a sweet, innocuous film nicely handled by director Peter Chelsom.

While The Salesman never quite soars it holds us in its grip from start to finish. It leaves us with much food for thought and the lingering question, "What would I do in a situation like this?" It's a very worthy Oscar nominee
Gold is as unpredictable as it is engaging-and another bull's-eye for Matthew McConaughey. The reason this movie works so well is that we believe the his character from the inside out

This film left me wanting. It seemed like a sure-fire story on the surface, which just proves how many things can go wrong from conception to execution. The Founder is as forgettable as a fast-food hamburger.

The film is a series of vignettes which occasionally show life and spark but eventually grow tiresome. There isn't much to take away from The Comedian except a reminder that De Niro remains the ultimate cinematic chameleon.

Movie Posters is enjoyable and informative, especially if you have a yen for the subject as I do. Kevin Burke's entertaining film is primarily about the renaissance of posters and its artists who don't restrict themselves to standard sizes

Gunn has given us a rousing piece of entertainment with plenty of action, ingenious ideas, and visual effects to engage us at every level. That's as much as anyone could ask of a movie, let alone a sequel.
This doc feels superficial and even redundant, especially if you've seen Alex Gibney's fascinating 2013 documentary We Steal Secrets: The Story of WikiLeaks. It's a real disappointment

Bang! is brimming with anecdotes from the people who knew Berns best. Bert Berns may not be a household name, but once you see this documentary you won't listen to his songs without thinking of the man behind those chart-toppers.
Tense, violent, well-staged, and suspenseful, Wind River is that rare bird nowadays: a good story well told.

America's history of racial violence and police abuse is shameful, but a great film on the subject should do more than merely reenact one notorious incident. I think we are owed something more. I wish Detroit provided that, but it doesn't
Dunkirk left me feeling vaguely dissatisfied, with too many unanswered questions. For me it missed the big picture. If that means I'm swimming against the tide, so be it.
This heavy-handed and unfunny film is a very strange movie for any audience, young or old.

The Big Sick is bracingly funny, heartrending, and intelligent, a perfect alternative to the pirates, mummies, and other creatures inhabiting multiplexes this summer. No wonder it was the runaway hit of this year's Sundance Film Festival.
I would recommend Score: A Film Music Documentary to any and every film buff.

Disarming in its simplicity while simultaneously being thoughtful and provocative--the skill of its execution make it compelling, even suspenseful at times. Whether or not you accept the conclusion is up to you.

I was glued to the screen from start to finish and when it was over I wanted more. If you love film you can't afford to miss the experience of seeing Bertrand Tavernier's Journey Through French Cinema, especially on a theater screen
movie_title: My Journey Through French Cinema (Voyage À Travers Le Cinéma Français) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I was mesmerized by this film--it's an exceptional piece of work, not to be missed.
This film tells two stories, both fascinating. Morrison's purposeful editing and story sense make Frozen Time a mesmerizing tale

Adam Driver is disarmingly sincere as a simple man who finds a meaningful outlet through poetry--and it's the filmmaker's ability to find something pleasing, possibly beautiful, in the ordinary that makes the movie worthwhile
Saying that Cars 3 is better than its predecessor isn't much of a compliment. What matters more is that it hearkens back to original 2006 Cars and winds up on a surprisingly thoughtful note.

Visual effects alone can't draw in an audience when a film is fatally overlong and we don't really care about the characters. I would offer one word of advice to the filmmakers, based on this cluttered remake of The Mummy: simplify.
Any good actor can wear makeup prosthetics and perform mimicry; Cox becomes Churchill, and he makes this film worth seeing.
The only wonder regarding this movie is that it could be so incredibly dull. I keep hoping DC will find a key to unlock the magic inherent in its great cast of characters.

This movie ought to be brainless summer fun. I'm sorry it isn't. No one expects Shakespearean dialogue or plotting in a movie based on the jiggly TV series of the 1990s, but even the breeziest summer escapism shouldn't be this stupid.

Boring. That's how I'd describe the latest Pirates film. Apparently, live men tell leaden tales like this, overstuffed with subplots and uninteresting characters. I'd rather walk the plank than spend another two hours with Jack Sparrow and company.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: War Machine is certainly worth seeing, but it doesn't score the direct hit I was hoping for. It's too bad that a handful of flaws work against the film's complete success.
Wakefield is an odd but consistently intriguing film, I found the result to be fascinating and provocative. The real magic here is in the audacious concept and its deft execution.

The alternate title for this latest space thriller might be Alien: Again. This B-movie trope seems unworthy of director Ridley Scott and company. While it's well-made and never dull, you can learn all the exposition you need from the trailer

Not every film is intended for a wide audience, I don't expect everyone to be swept away by Eleanor Coppola's romantic travelogue. This film celebrates the beauty of France and the importance of stopping and smelling the roses

A film starring two A-list comediennes should, at the very least, be funny. Snatched fails on this count but also seems to have other ambitions. A talented cast and crew just can't make this film come together, and that's a real shame
Maudie scores high for good intentions and solid work by its stars. Its story is one-of-a-kind but I wish I hadn't felt so conscious of the wheels turning as it unfolded.
Landing short of the "Skyfall" bar, "Spectre" still glides in at an above average action fare film.
When was it decided superhero movies shouldn't be any fun?
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With superb performances from Mulligan and crew, "Suffragette" should be a heartfelt winner... instead...
The heartbeat of "Transcendence" comes from solid performances in the leading roles.
"Fading Gigolo" is a sweet, bracingly original, wholly entertaining film from John Turturro with a plum part for none other than Woody Allen.
"Joe" paints a rich, multilayered portrait of a hardscrabble existence in this community, not unlike the world we encountered in Debra Granik's "Winter's Bone."
Director Ivan Reitman steers an expert cast through its paces, with Kevin Costner in a tailor-made leading role.
On the face of it, "Only Lovers Left Alive" is original and intriguing: Tilda Swinton and Tom Hiddleston play vampires who have been married for centuries.
Truth is usually stranger, and often more intriguing, than fiction, and this well-told narrative is a perfect example.
movie_title: The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came To Eden (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Drake Doremus and his writing partner Ben York Jones' working method is unorthodox... and earlier films have established them as a creative team who have much on the ball...
"Noah" is a long road from Darren Aronofsky's audacious debut feature "pi" to this $130 million dollar epic, but the filmmaker is still an original thinker and visualist.
Is "Muppets Most Wanted" a likable picture? Of course; we're talking about Kermit the Frog, Fozzie Bear and Miss Piggy after all.
"Divergent" has an empathetic heroine, an intriguing premise to keep it afloat, and enough twists to sustain it...
"Brooklyn" delivers pure enjoyment in its storytelling, visuals, characters and, most of all, its leading lady.
You'd have to be inept not to get good material when you turn a camera on the irrepressible Elaine Stritch. Fortunately, first-time director Chiemi Karasawa earned the actress' complete trust...
Certainly no one else would render such a story in old-school, hand-drawn animation instead of surrendering to modern CGI. But that's what makes Miyazaki unique

The premise of "The Pretty One" may be far-fetched, but it's carried out with sincerity and the results are amusing, ironic, and thoughtful. Here's a small-scale movie that offers a gleam of satisfaction.
"Robocop" marks Brazilian documentarian-turned action director José Padilha's American debut, but it doesn't reveal anything other than an ability to execute high-octane action scenes.
It's rare to find a movie that isn't ironic or aloof, especially in its overarching goal, to pay tribute to an unpopular enterprise that paid off for posterity.
Kate Winslet is completely believable as a woman who can no longer face even the simplest tasks and Josh Brolin brings both warmth and effortless authority to his character..
An improbable subject has inspired a unique documentary which comes with an unusual pedigree: it was produced by those inventive magicians Penn and Teller, and directed by Teller.
Without a moral center, "Wolf" seems to revel in this cornucopia of bad behavior.
As a showcase for a host of gifted actors, "August: Osage County" is potent and entertaining.
There are no false heroics here, only the bravery of men under fire who trust each other with their very lives.
"Godzilla" is a terrific piece of entertainment that doesn't insult its audience and gives us more than our money's worth.
Writer-director Asghar Farhad works so well with his actors that everything seems genuine and naturalistic, even the scenes involving young children.
"God's Pocket" is the kind of film I usually root for: a collage of vignettes about offbeat, colorful characters, played by an A-list cast including the late, great Philip Seymour Hoffman
"Belle" is handsome and well-cast with Gugu Mbatha-Raw, who made an impression on me in Tom Hanks' "Larry Crowne," in the title role.
With massive doses of eye-popping special effects I applaud the visual achievements in 'Dawn of the Planet of the Apes.'
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Filmmaker Richard Linklater has long since earned his reputation as an original thinker but his latest work, 'Boyhood,' is in a class by itself.
In Melissa McCarthy and Ben Falcone's 'Tammy,' Susan Sarandon effortlessly dominates every scene she's in and keeps her character grounded and real...
'How to Train Your Dragon 2' is a rich and satisfying movie of surprising substance.
'22 Jump Street' tries to catch a meta-wave on the shoulders of its stars, Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum.
'Jersey Boys,' a rags-to-riches tale with glimpses behind the scenes of the music business, is pretty well irresistible.
When the most interesting thing in 'Transformers: Age of Extinction' is the blatant product placement, you know something is out of whack.
'Words and Pictures' leans heavily on the considerable appeal of its stars and the touch of its director, Fred Schepisi, who maintains a light hand throughout
'Obvious Child' is a small-scale but winning comedy from writer-director Gillian Robespierre and leading lady Jenny Slate.
If you love show-business stories, as I do, you'll lap up Supermensch.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: 'Edge Of Tomorrow,' with an intriguing premise and the ability to see it through to a satisfying conclusion, is more than razzle-dazzle visual effects.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Shailene Woodley is reason enough to see 'The Fault in Our Stars.'
"The Angriest Man in Brooklyn" doesn't seem to know what chord to strike: it veers wildly from madcap farce to social satire to sentimental family drama.
It's fairly plain that "A Night in Old Mexico" is a vehicle for Duvall, and as such it's thoroughly enjoyable; watching him is a genuine treat.
One of "The Immigrant's" primary assets is its texture: a rich fabric of sights and sounds that evoke the look and feel of New York's underbelly in the early 20th century.
"Million Dollar Arm" benefits from a strong performance by Jon Hamm in the lead and a top-notch supporting cast.
"A Million Ways To Die In The West" may remind MacFarlane's core audience of what they're missing by not having Westerns as part of their regular movie menu.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "X-Men: Days Of Future Past" is vibrant and entertaining.
In "Maleficent" a lush fairy-tale world is created and the result is truly magical.
It's small in scale but well worth seeing, especially if (like me) you've missed seeing Griffin Dunne.

"Devil's Knot" screenwriters Paul Harris Boardman and Scott Derrickson, and the talented director Atom Egoyan, paint a picture of the principal figures in the case of the West Memphis Three and the community where the crimes took place.
I don't demand a great deal from a glossy Hollywood comedy, but it would be nice to find a smarter, more original piece of work than this in the year 2014.
At a time when so many comedies try to push the boundary lines of raunchiness as far as they can, this one deals in another, much rarer, commodity: sheer silliness.
On the plus side of the ledger, Russell enables his cast to inhabit some colorful, downright transformative, characters.
A charming and heartwarming piece of entertainment, highlighted by a handful of superior performances.
Tidbits of trashy, eyebrow-raising fun but... the characters aren't very bright, and the movie gets dumber...
Bloodworth Thomason's film is effective because it tells one couple's story and allows it to implicitly represent thousands of others.
Radcliffe is particularly good as the bright, naïve young man who seeks escape from an oppressive home life with his poet-father and mentally unstable mother...
Redford is the film's most credible ingredient of all; in many key scenes it is evident that he is performing his own stunts.
Director Steve McQueen was clearly the right man to execute an unflinching adaptation of Solomon Northup's incredible story.
The bullet points of WikiLeaks' rise and fall are dutifully covered, but the movie bites off more than it can chew...
Director Paul Greengrass and cinematographer Barry Ackroyd create a vivid, insider's look at life at sea and how a crew of twenty did their best to elude their would-be captors.
Few New York City photos are as familiar or evocative as the one that inspired the documentary "Men At Lunch."
A thoughtful, intimate documentary about a blues shouter, in the tradition of the great Joe Turner...
"Gravity" is a knock out, but without Bullock's movie-star charisma and everywoman relatability, the film wouldn't work nearly as well as it does.
As someone who clearly remembers that November afternoon in 1963, and the days that followed, I was drawn to all of the detail in "Parkland."
De Niro is a pleasure to watch in a role that calls on him to exercise his comedic chops with some degree of subtlety.
The old-fashioned, old-school wizardry of MGM still looks impressive to me today...
"Prisoners" is gripping and exceptionally well made, but I found it relentless-too bleak for my taste...
Ron Howard has brought this story to life with unbridled energy, transforming each race into an adrenaline-charged vignette that could serve as a master class in staging and editing action scenes.
Filmmaker Kornbluth personalizes this story by using Reich's warmth and humor to win us over and keep his presentation from becoming a dry recitation of facts.
The movie picks up where the last one left off, but the sequel bears little resemblance to 2009's "Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs."
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Every detail of this modest film is well thought out and executed, from the spot-on casting to the canny use of sound and music...
Louis-Dreyfuss reveals colors and shadings we've never seen before, while Gandolfini is irresistibly likable in his least characteristic role.
A great ensemble infuses life into the characters, but it's as if Shelton has painted herself into a corner with no clue what to do next.

In portraying a wide range of attitudes and experiences writer-director Cretton never strikes a false note; if anything, you could almost be fooled into believing this is a fly-on-the-wall documentary.
Writer-director Wladyslaw Pasikowski has structured "Aftermath" like a mystery; revealing itself one layer at a time
Director Jon Turteltaub and screenwriter Dan Fogelman have upped their game here, with four gifted actors at their command
Though it's taken twenty-some years to reach the screen, "Dallas Buyer's Club" has been made with such care and commitment that I'd say it's been worth the wait.
The futuristic setting of the piece is beautifully realized, but it's the emotional quotient that dominates and drives the film.
The hand-to-hand combat that fills the movie is seamlessly integrated into a make-believe world created by the magicians at Jackson's WETA workshop
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: You have to admire Joel and Ethan Coen's ability to put a personal stamp on everything they do.
Director and co-writer Scott Cooper never finds a way to transform his working-class parable into a meaningful story in "Out of the Furnace."
Mark Mori has created a film that, at one time, would have been deemed impossible: a thorough, even-handed chronicle of the pin-up queen's life.
The always-imposing Idris Elba does a fine job interpreting the (now) larger-than-life figure of Nelson Mandela...
There's never a dull moment in "Frozen," which throws in a fearsome snow monster, a life-and-death race to rescue one of its principals, and unexpected character twists..
"Philomena" is a moving story that serves as a perfect vehicle for the incomparable Judi Dench.
Unlike most Hollywood remakes of foreign-language pictures, "Delivery Man" was made by the same filmmaker responsible for the French-Canadian hit "Starbuck."
This follow-up to the 2012 hit based on Suzanne Collins' novel, represents commendable storytelling that ought to please the book's many fans
...the "best in show" was a remarkably well-told account of a unique human being...
'Land Ho!' filmmakers Martha Stephens and Aaron Katz created a stir with this one at Sundance, however...
You don't have to agree with Abu-Jamal's politics to admire his work ethic-or his eloquence.
"Brave Miss World" is a compelling, empathetic profile of a gutsy Israeli woman...
Alexander Payne has the confidence to allow "Nebraska" to unfold at a leisurely pace. I liked it the first time I saw it...
"About Time" uses an ingenious and original comic device, built around the most irresistible commodity any movie can offer...
This adaptation of Meg Rosoff's young adult novel hasn't much to recommend it except the presence of Saoirse Ronan in the leading role.
"The Book Thief" treads on familiar ground... the situations are realistic, the moral choices genuine, and the emotions honestly portrayed.
Loki... fittingly, gets all the best moments and the actor clearly relishes the way his character enjoys being evil.
By keeping their goals modest the filmmakers have given us a pleasant-enough romantic comedy.
Jehane Noujaim's "The Square" is a riveting, eye-opening experience, told with empathy and immediacy.
In his impressively researched film, Donahue makes it clear why and how Dougherty helped define her profession.
This is not a slickly packaged reality-show experience. Through the filmmakers, Shasta Grenier and Sabrina Lee, we become witnesses to an evolutionary process.
Judy Chaikin's loving documentary about vaudeville, big bands, and jazz, is a standout...
Joe Berlinger's documentary 'Whitey' is so hard-hitting and compelling, you can't take your eyes off the screen.
movie_title: Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A deft blending of thriller and romance, "Omar" invokes everything from film noir to Shakespeare.
Filmmaker Mike Cahill deals with serious subjects, science and spirituality, in an entertaining way in his latest 'I, Origins.'
Everything about "Spy" works which makes it the one to beat as the best comedy of the year.
Optimistic spirit makes up for flaws in "Tomorrowland."
Intimate and absorbing with a timely message that's right on target.
Furiously on-target for action junkies and fan-boys...
Joss Whedon set a higher bar with the first "Avengers" (2012) and tried, in many ways, to top it here. He got close...
Carey Mulligan captures the effervescent determination of Thomas Hardy's literary heroine in this onscreen adaptation.
With Ex Machina writer/director Alex Garfield delivers a science fiction film full of concepts and ideas versus overblown visual effects.
Takes no names. Saves no places... The racing franchise continues bigger and better...
A skilled cast fails to lift a morbidly recounted true tale...
A wholly captivating Mirren makes Woman in Gold a positive film-going experience...
In filmmaker Baumbach's contemporary comedy, Stiller and Watts never lose sight of their connection with each other even while examining their life choices.
Kevin Hart gives his all, but infectious energy does little to rescue the heavy-handedness of Get Hard.
This likable movie rises or falls on Al Pacino's ability to convince us that he's an aging pop star... and he does.
As with District 9, the interaction between the title character and his human co-stars is seamless and absolutely real... In fact, the film's visuals are its primary achievement.
This is a crowd pleasing movie... Sad to say, I'm not in agreement with the crowd...
One of Kevin Costner's finest performance... A well-told story told that is full of heart
"Fifty Shades of Grey," which gingerly crosses over into the questionable subject mark, may not be the film some of the book's readers were hoping to witness.
No need to be a sports fan to become enthralled with "Red Army." The documentary held me in its grip from start to finish.
The main attraction in "Cake" is Aniston...
Pacino excels in "The Humbling," a complex drama which seems, almost, tailor-made for the actor.
Julianne Moore is the main reason to see "Still Alice. "
Brittain's autobiographical story of substance is a timely reminder of the hard choices made when going to war.
A good-hearted film... as witty and clever as it is charming...
Ranks, on every front, as one of the best from Marvel's universe!
We can only marvel at what writer-director Nolan has thought up and executed so well. But he doesn't know when to stop. Every level leads to another level.
Under Fukunaga's expert guidance the camerawork nearly becomes a third character alongside the real find in the film, newcomer Abraham Attah as Agu.
Cate Blanchett anchors this aptly dramatized look at the circumstances surrounding the discovery and revelations behind Abu Ghraib...
Moving, real, surprising and dramatic... a delicate balance ably handled by director, Abrahamson. See it before letting the buzz seep in...
As an entire piece, the film lands on the upper end of the Superior Scale, but it's Hanks' performance that makes it the reason to go to the movies.
Gothically impressive visuals rise... story unfortunately fizzles.
A closer look at the incredible journey-thus far--of Malala Yousafzai...a young girl, far wiser than her 18 years...
The combination of Reynolds and Mendelsohn makes this a sure bet...
A fantasy-like tale of a real-life adventure...
Absorbing, entertaining drama with an on-target message...
Fassbender delivers a mesmeric performance as Jobs...
The subtle performances of the leads, the remarkable Irrfan Khan and the engaging Nimrat Kaur, make 'The Lunchbox' a pleasure to watch.
Nothing fresh about "The Intern."
Stellar talent soars in this stranger than fiction true life gangster tale.
'The Second Mother' comprises striking production design, a provocative screenplay, and most of all the commanding, genuine, and often hilarious performance of its leading lady.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Ponsoldt's done it again in this insightful two-character piece with piercing performances by Segel and Eisenberg.
A group of talented young actors in a bio-pic that packs a punch in all the right places... eye-opening and compelling...
A mostly satisfying narrative that benefits from the gifted ensemble of players...
The movie may not be great, or even memorable, but I had a good time watching it... and that is no small compliment.
A Summer Blockbuster worth the title: in MI's fifth installment, the Cruise gung-ho approach cements why he's a true movie hero!
A first-rate, first-person dissection of his life by the talented, charming and oft-troubled actor, Brando.
What a pleasure it is to be in the presence of Ian McKellen, who dominates the screen in Mr. Holmes.
Amy Schumer scores a smash with a little help from Judd Apatow.
Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne, comme d'habitude, deliver first-rate, suspenseful drama with an approach not unlike the cinéma vérité style associated with documentary filmmaking...
Matt Damon lands on solid ground in 'The Martian,' ... nothing less than superior entertainment...
A film of heartbreak and humor, which tells a story of considerable size and weight...yet despite its ambitions there is not an ounce of pretense.
Not since Spike Lee's early work has there been a movie so full of provocative ideas-and a sly sense of humor.
At the heart of 'Birdman' is a gallery of sharply-etched performances, with Michael Keaton, who leads the way, being well-matched by Zach Galifianakis.
For a male audience that craves action, 'Fury' delivers the goods and Brad Pitt is a plus, in his role, as a World War II swaggering tank commander.
Writer-director Damien Chazelle grabs us with his dynamic story and holds us in the palm of his hand from beginning to end.
If you're willing to go along for this farcical ride, you'll find 'Dead Snow 2' to be one terrific zombie movie.
